fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: Events
fields.description: events array

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: Endpoint
fields.title: Endpoint
fields.description: Fields describing the state of the Elastic Endpoint when an event occurs.

fields.name: policy
fields.description: The policy fields are used to hold information about applied policy.

fields.name: policy.applied.version

fields.name: Memory_protection
fields.title: Memory Protection
fields.description: These fields contain information specific to Memory Protection alerts.

fields.name: cross_session
fields.description: Is this process injecting across operating system sessions?

fields.name: feature
fields.description: Memory Protection feature which triggered the alert.

fields.name: parent_to_child
fields.description: Is this process injecting into its child?

fields.name: self_injection
fields.description: Is this alert about a process injecting into itself?

fields.name: thread_count
fields.description: The number of threads that this alert applies to. If several alerts occur in a short period of time, they can be combined into a single alert with thread_count > 1.

fields.name: unique_key_v1
fields.description: A unique key created by hashing several characteristics of this alert.

fields.name: unique_key_v2
fields.description: A unique key created by hashing several characteristics of this alert.

fields.description: Full path to the file, including the file name.

fields.description: Process id.

fields.description: Total ransomware score for aggregated file events.

fields.name: child_processes.version
fields.description: Ransomware artifact version.

fields.name: Target
fields.title: Target
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a target.
These fields provide more context about the target process and thread that are related to the data in the document. Useful in a security context where a target process or thread may be acted on by another process or thread.

fields.name: dll.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: dll.Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: dll.Ext.compile_time
fields.description: Timestamp from when the module was compiled.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.features
fields.description: Intermediate field included by adding option with subset

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.buffer
fields.description: The features extracted from this file and evaluated by the model.  Usually an array of floats.  Likely zlib-encoded.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.decompressed_size
fields.description: The decompressed size of buffer.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.encoding
fields.description: The encoding of buffer (e.g. zlib).

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.identifier
fields.description: The model's unique identifier.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.score
fields.description: The score produced by the classification model.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.threshold
fields.description: The score threshold for the model.  Files that score above this threshold are considered malicious.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.upx_packed
fields.description: Whether UPX packing was detected.

fields.name: dll.Ext.malware_classification.version
fields.description: The version of the model used.

fields.name: dll.Ext.mapped_address
fields.description: The base address where this module is loaded.

fields.name: dll.Ext.mapped_size
fields.description: The size of this module's memory mapping, in bytes.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: dll.code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: dll.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: dll.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: dll.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: dll.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: dll.hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: dll.name
fields.description:
Name of the library.
This generally maps to the name of the file on disk.

fields.name: dll.path
fields.description: Full file path of the library.

fields.name: dll.pe.company
fields.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: dll.pe.description
fields.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: dll.pe.file_version
fields.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: dll.pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: dll.pe.original_file_name
fields.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: dll.pe.product
fields.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this indicates the offset of original_start_address from the allocation base.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.original_start_address_bytes_disasm

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.original_start_address_module
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this indicates the original content for the dll/module where the thread began execution.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.parameter
fields.description: When a thread is created, this is the raw numerical value of its parameter.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.parameter_bytes_compressed
fields.description: Up to 512KB of raw data from the thread parameter, if it is a valid pointer. This is compressed with zlib. To reduce data volume, this is de-duplicated on the endpoint, and may be missing from many alerts if the same data would be sent multiple times.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.parameter_bytes_compressed_present

fields.description: The time the thread started.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.start_address_allocation_offset
fields.description: Offset of start_address into the memory allocation. Equal to start_address - start_address_details.allocation_base.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.start_address_bytes

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.start_address_bytes_disasm
fields.description: The bytes at the thread start address, disassembled into human-readable assembly code.

fields.name: process.thread.Ext.start_address_bytes_disasm_hash
fields.description: The bytes at the thread start address, with immediate values capped to 0x100, disassembled into human-readable assembly code, then hashed.

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: ephemeral_id
fields.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this agent (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `agent.id` does not.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Custom name of the agent.
This is a name that can be given to an agent. This can be helpful if for example two Filebeat instances are running on the same host but a human readable separation is needed on which Filebeat instance data is coming from.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: cloud
fields.title: Cloud
fields.description: Fields related to the cloud or infrastructure the events are coming from.

fields.name: account.id
fields.description:
The cloud account or organization id used to identify different entities in a multi-tenant environment.
Examples: AWS account id, Google Cloud ORG Id, or other unique identifier.

fields.name: instance.name
fields.description: Instance name of the host machine.

fields.name: project.id
fields.description:
The cloud project identifier.
Examples: Google Cloud Project id, Azure Project id.

fields.name: provider
fields.description: Name of the cloud provider. Example values are aws, azure, gcp, or digitalocean.

fields.name: region
fields.description: Region in which this host, resource, or service is located.

fields.footnote:
Examples: If Metricbeat is running on an EC2 host and fetches data from its host, the cloud info contains the data about this machine. If Metricbeat runs on a remote machine outside the cloud and fetches data from a service running in the cloud, the field contains cloud data from the machine the service is running on.
The cloud fields may be self-nested under cloud.origin.* and cloud.target.* to describe origin or target service's cloud information in the context of incoming or outgoing requests, respectively. However, the fieldsets cloud.origin.* and cloud.target.* must not be confused with the root cloud fieldset that is used to describe the cloud context of the actual service under observation. The fieldset cloud.origin.* may only be used in the context of incoming requests or events to provide the originating service's cloud information. The fieldset cloud.target.* may only be used in the context of outgoing requests or events to describe the target service's cloud information.

fields.name: container
fields.title: Container
fields.description:
Container fields are used for meta information about the specific container that is the source of information.
These fields help correlate data based containers from any runtime.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique container id.

fields.name: image.name
fields.description: Name of the image the container was built on.

fields.name: image.tag
fields.description: Container image tags.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Container name.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: destination
fields.title: Destination
fields.description:
Destination fields capture details about the receiver of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Destination fields are usually populated in conjunction with source fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: IP address of the destination (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: dll
fields.title: DLL
fields.description:
These fields contain information about code libraries dynamically loaded into processes.

Many operating systems refer to "shared code libraries" with different names, but this field set refers to all of the following:
* Dynamic-link library (`.dll`) commonly used on Windows
* Shared Object (`.so`) commonly used on Unix-like operating systems
* Dynamic library (`.dylib`) commonly used on macOS

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.compile_time
fields.description: Timestamp from when the module was compiled.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features
fields.description: Intermediate field included by adding option with subset

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.buffer
fields.description: The features extracted from this file and evaluated by the model.  Usually an array of floats.  Likely zlib-encoded.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.decompressed_size
fields.description: The decompressed size of buffer.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.encoding
fields.description: The encoding of buffer (e.g. zlib).

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.identifier
fields.description: The model's unique identifier.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.score
fields.description: The score produced by the classification model.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.threshold
fields.description: The score threshold for the model.  Files that score above this threshold are considered malicious.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.upx_packed
fields.description: Whether UPX packing was detected.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.version
fields.description: The version of the model used.

fields.name: Ext.mapped_address
fields.description: The base address where this module is loaded.

fields.name: Ext.mapped_size
fields.description: The size of this module's memory mapping, in bytes.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the library.
This generally maps to the name of the file on disk.

fields.name: path
fields.description: Full file path of the library.

fields.name: pe.company
fields.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.description
fields.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.file_version
fields.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: pe.original_file_name
fields.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.product
fields.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: dns
fields.title: DNS
fields.description:
Fields describing DNS queries and answers.
DNS events should either represent a single DNS query prior to getting answers (`dns.type:query`) or they should represent a full exchange and contain the query details as well as all of the answers that were provided for this query (`dns.type:answer`).

fields.name: question.name
fields.description:
The name being queried.
If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.

fields.name: question.type
fields.description: The type of record being queried.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: elastic
fields.title: Elastic
fields.description: Holds fields and properties of data points and concepts in the elastic domain or namespace.

fields.name: agent
fields.description: The agent fields contain data about the Elastic Agent. The Elastic Agent is the management agent that manages other agents or process on the host.

fields.name: agent.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of this elastic agent (if one exists).

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: risk_score
fields.description: Risk score or priority of the event (e.g. security solutions). Use your system's original value here.

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: file
fields.title: File
fields.description:
A file is defined as a set of information that has been created on, or has existed on a filesystem.
File objects can be associated with host events, network events, and/or file events (e.g., those produced by File Integrity Monitoring [FIM] products or services). File fields provide details about the affected file associated with the event or metric.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.entry_modified
fields.description: Time of last status change.  See `st_ctim` member of `struct stat`.

fields.name: Ext.macro.code_page
fields.description: Identifies the character encoding used for this macro.  https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/intl/code-page-identifiers

fields.name: Ext.macro.collection
fields.description: Object containing hashes for the macro collection.

fields.name: Ext.macro.collection.hash.md5

fields.name: Ext.macro.collection.hash.sha1

fields.name: Ext.macro.collection.hash.sha256

fields.name: Ext.macro.collection.hash.sha512

fields.name: Ext.macro.errors

fields.name: Ext.macro.errors.count

fields.name: Ext.macro.errors.error_type

fields.name: Ext.macro.file_extension
fields.description: The extension of the file containing this macro (e.g. .docm)

fields.name: Ext.macro.project_file
fields.description: Metadata about the corresponding VBA project file

fields.name: Ext.macro.project_file.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.project_file.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.project_file.hash.sha256

fields.name: Ext.macro.project_file.hash.sha512

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream
fields.description: Streams associated with the document.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.name
fields.description: Name of the stream.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.raw_code
fields.description: First 100KB of raw stream binary.  Can be useful to analyze false positives and malicious payloads.

fields.name: Ext.macro.stream.raw_code_size
fields.description: The original stream size.  Indicates whether stream.raw_code was truncated.

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features
fields.description: Intermediate field included by adding option with subset

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.buffer

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.decompressed_size

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.features.data.encoding

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.identifier

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.score

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.threshold

fields.name: Ext.malware_classification.upx_packed

fields.name: Ext.original
fields.description: Original file information during a modification event.

fields.name: Ext.original.gid

fields.name: Ext.original.mode

fields.name: Ext.original.name

fields.name: Ext.original.path

fields.name: Ext.original.uid

fields.name: Ext.quarantine_message
fields.description: Message describing quarantine results.

fields.name: Ext.quarantine_path

fields.name: Ext.quarantine_result
fields.description: Boolean representing whether or not file quarantine succeeded.

fields.name: Ext.temp_file_path
fields.description: Path on endpoint where a copy of the file is being stored.  Used to make ephemeral files retrievable.

fields.name: Ext.windows
fields.description: Platform-specific Windows fields

fields.name: Ext.windows.zone_identifier
fields.description: Windows zone identifier for a file

fields.name: accessed
fields.description:
Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

fields.name: attributes
fields.description:
Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

fields.name: ctime
fields.description:
Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

fields.name: device
fields.description: Device that is the source of the file.

fields.name: directory
fields.description: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: drive_letter
fields.description:
Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

fields.name: extension
fields.description:
File extension, excluding the leading dot.
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

fields.name: gid
fields.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

fields.name: group
fields.description: Primary group name of the file.

fields.name: hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: inode
fields.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

fields.name: mime_type
fields.description: MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml[IANA official types], where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

fields.name: mode
fields.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.

fields.name: mtime
fields.description: Last time the file content was modified.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

fields.name: owner
fields.description: File owner's username.

fields.name: path
fields.description: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: pe.Ext.dotnet
fields.description: Whether this file is a .NET PE

fields.name: pe.Ext.sections
fields.description: The file's relevant sections, if it is a PE

fields.name: pe.Ext.sections.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: pe.Ext.sections.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: pe.Ext.sections.name
fields.description: The section's name

fields.name: pe.Ext.streams
fields.description: The file's streams, if it is a PE

fields.name: pe.Ext.streams.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: pe.Ext.streams.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: pe.Ext.streams.name
fields.description: The stream's name

fields.name: pe.company
fields.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.description
fields.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.file_version
fields.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: pe.original_file_name
fields.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: pe.product
fields.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: size
fields.description:
File size in bytes.
Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".

fields.name: target_path
fields.description: Target path for symlinks.

fields.name: type
fields.description: File type (file, dir, or symlink).

fields.name: uid
fields.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

fields.name: group
fields.title: Group
fields.description: The group fields are meant to represent groups that are relevant to the event.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: boot.id
fields.description: Linux boot uuid taken from /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id. Note the boot_id value from /proc may or may not be the same in containers as on the host. Some container runtimes will bind mount a new boot_id value onto the proc file in each container.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: pid_ns_ino
fields.description: This is the inode number of the namespace in the namespace file system (nsfs). Unsigned int inum in include/linux/ns_common.h.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.

fields.name: user.email

fields.name: user.full_name

fields.name: user.hash

Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

fields.name: user.name

fields.name: process
fields.title: Process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a process.
These fields can help you correlate metrics information with a process id/name from a log message.  The `process.pid` often stays in the metric itself and is copied to the global field for correlation.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.ancestry
fields.description: An array of entity_ids indicating the ancestors for this event

fields.name: Ext.api.behaviors
fields.description:
A list of observed behaviors.
  "cross-process" - the observed activity was between two processes
  "parent-child" - the observed activity was between a parent process and its child
  "native_api" - a call was made directly to the Native API rather than the Win32 API
  "direct_syscall" - a syscall instruction originated outside of the Native API layer
  "proxy_call" - the call stack may indicate of a proxied API call to mask the true source
  "sensitive_api" - executable non-image memory is unexpectedly calling a sensitive API
  "shellcode" - suspicious executable non-image memory is calling a sensitive API
  "image_hooked" - an entry in the callstack appears to have been hooked
  "image_indirect_call" - an entry in the callstack was preceded by a call to a dynamically resolved function
  "image_rop" - no call instruction preceded an entry in the call stack
  "image_rwx" - an entry in the callstack is writable
  "unbacked_rwx" - an entry in the callstack is non-image and writable
  "truncated_stack" - call stack is unexpected truncated due to malicious tampering or system load
  "allocate_shellcode" - a region of non-image executable memory allocated more executable memory
  "execute_fluctuation" - the PAGE_EXECUTE protection is unexpectedly fluctuating
  "write_fluctuation" - the PAGE_WRITE protection of executable memory is unexpectedly fluctuating
  "hook_api" - a change to the memory protection of a small executable image memory region was made
  "hollow_image" - a change to the memory protection of a large executable image memory region was made
  "hook_unbacked" - a change to the memory protection of a small executable non-image memory was made
  "hollow_unbacked" - a change to the memory protection of a large executable non-image memory was made
  "guarded_code" - executable memory was unexpectedly marked as PAGE_GUARD
  "hidden_code" - executable memory was unexpectedly marked as PAGE_NOACCESS
  "execute_shellcode" - a region of non-image executable memory was unexpectedly transferred control
  "hardware_breakpoint_set" - a hardware breakpoint was set
  "rapid_background_polling" - a suspicious process which does rapid input polling via GetAsyncKeyState API was observed
  "multiple_polling_processes" - multiple suspicious processes which do rapid input polling via the GetAsyncKeyState API were observed
  "pid_spoofing" - The acting process details may have been spoofed to hide the true origin
  "legacy_api" - a deprecated or superseded API was called

fields.name: Ext.api.summary

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.created_suspended
fields.description: A heuristic indicating if the CREATE_SUSPENDED flag was passed to the Win32 CreateProcess API. Not valid for direct syscalls.

fields.name: command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entry_leader.args_count
fields.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

fields.name: entry_leader.command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entry_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.entry_meta.source.ip
fields.description: IP address of the source (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: entry_leader.entry_meta.type
fields.description:
The entry type for the entry session leader. Values include: init(e.g systemd), sshd, ssm, kubelet, teleport, terminal, console
Note: This field is only set on process.session_leader.

fields.name: entry_leader.executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: entry_leader.group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.interactive
fields.description:
Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

fields.name: entry_leader.name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.start
fields.description: The time the process started.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.start
fields.description: The time the process started.

fields.name: entry_leader.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.same_as_process
fields.description:
This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.start

fields.name: entry_leader.tty.char_device.major
fields.description: The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

fields.name: entry_leader.tty.char_device.minor
fields.description: The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel don’t use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

fields.name: group_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: group_leader.executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: group_leader.group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group_leader.group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group_leader.interactive
fields.description:
Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

fields.name: group_leader.real_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: group_leader.same_as_process
fields.description:
This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

fields.name: thread.Ext

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.memory_section.memory_address

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.memory_section.memory_size

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.module_path

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.rva

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.symbol_info

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.hash
fields.description: Hashes of the call_stack_final_hook_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.hash.sha256

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature
fields.description: Code signature of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.exists

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.hash
fields.description: Hashes of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.hash.sha256

fields.name: thread.Ext.hardware_breakpoint_set
fields.description: Whether a hardware breakpoint was set for the thread. This field is omitted if false.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this indicates the original content for the thread start address in memory.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address_allocation_offset
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this indicates the offset of original_start_address from the allocation base.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address_bytes
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this holds the hex-encoded bytes at the original thread start address.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address_bytes_disasm
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this holds the disassembled code at the original thread start address.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address_bytes_disasm_hash
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this holds the bytes at the original thread start address, with immediate values capped to 0x100, disassembled into human-readable assembly code, then hashed.

fields.name: thread.Ext.original_start_address_module
fields.description: When a trampoline was detected, this indicates the original content for the dll/module where the thread began execution.

fields.name: thread.Ext.parameter
fields.description: When a thread is created, this is the raw numerical value of its parameter.

fields.name: thread.Ext.parameter_bytes_compressed
fields.description: Up to 512KB of raw data from the thread parameter, if it is a valid pointer. This is compressed with zlib. To reduce data volume, this is de-duplicated on the endpoint, and may be missing from many alerts if the same data would be sent multiple times.

fields.name: thread.Ext.parameter_bytes_compressed_present
fields.description: Whether parameter_bytes_compressed is present in this event.

fields.name: thread.Ext.service
fields.description: Service associated with the thread.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start
fields.description: The time the thread started.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address
fields.description: Memory address where the thread began execution.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address_allocation_offset
fields.description: Offset of start_address into the memory allocation. Equal to start_address - start_address_details.allocation_base.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address_bytes
fields.description: A few (typically 32) raw opcode bytes at the thread start address, hex-encoded.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address_bytes_disasm
fields.description: The bytes at the thread start address, disassembled into human-readable assembly code.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address_bytes_disasm_hash
fields.description: The bytes at the thread start address, with immediate values capped to 0x100, disassembled into human-readable assembly code, then hashed.

fields.name: thread.Ext.start_address_module
fields.description: The dll/module where the thread began execution.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.domain
fields.description: Domain of token user.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.elevation
fields.description: Whether the token is elevated or not

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.elevation_type
fields.description: What level of elevation the token has

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.impersonation_level
fields.description: Impersonation level. Only valid for impersonation tokens.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.integrity_level
fields.description: Numeric integrity level.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.integrity_level_name
fields.description: Human readable integrity level.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.is_appcontainer
fields.description: Whether or not this is an appcontainer token.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.privileges
fields.description: Array describing the privileges associated with the token.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.privileges.description
fields.description: Description of the privilege.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.privileges.enabled
fields.description: Whether or not the privilege is enabled.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.privileges.name
fields.description: Name of the privilege.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.sid
fields.description: Token user's Security Identifier (SID).

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.type
fields.description: Type of the token, either primary or impersonation.

fields.name: thread.Ext.token.user
fields.description: Username of token owner.

fields.name: thread.Ext.uptime
fields.description: Seconds since thread started.

fields.name: thread.id
fields.description: Thread ID.

fields.name: thread.name
fields.description: Thread name.

fields.name: title
fields.description:
Process title.
The proctitle, some times the same as process name. Can also be different: for example a browser setting its title to the web page currently opened.

fields.name: tty
fields.description: Information about the controlling TTY device. If set, the process belongs to an interactive session.

fields.name: tty.char_device.major
fields.description: The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

fields.name: tty.char_device.minor
fields.description: The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel don’t use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the process has been up.

fields.name: user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: working_directory
fields.description: The working directory of the process.

fields.name: registry
fields.title: Registry
fields.description: Fields related to Windows Registry operations.

fields.name: data.strings
fields.description:
Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

fields.name: path
fields.description: Full path, including hive, key and value

fields.name: value
fields.description: Name of the value written.

fields.name: rule
fields.title: Rule
fields.description:
Rule fields are used to capture the specifics of any observer or agent rules that generate alerts or other notable events.
Examples of data sources that would populate the rule fields include: network admission control platforms, network or host IDS/IPS, network firewalls, web application firewalls, url filters, endpoint detection and response (EDR) systems, etc.

fields.name: author
fields.description: Name, organization, or pseudonym of the author or authors who created the rule used to generate this event.

fields.name: category
fields.description: A categorization value keyword used by the entity using the rule for detection of this event.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the rule generating the event.
fields.example: Block requests to public DNS over HTTPS / TLS protocols

fields.name: id
fields.description: A rule ID that is unique within the scope of an agent, observer, or other entity using the rule for detection of this event.

fields.name: license
fields.description: Name of the license under which the rule used to generate this event is made available.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The name of the rule or signature generating the event.

fields.name: reference
fields.description:
Reference URL to additional information about the rule used to generate this event.
The URL can point to the vendor's documentation about the rule. If that's not available, it can also be a link to a more general page describing this type of alert.

fields.name: ruleset
fields.description: Name of the ruleset, policy, group, or parent category in which the rule used to generate this event is a member.

fields.name: uuid
fields.description: A rule ID that is unique within the scope of a set or group of agents, observers, or other entities using the rule for detection of this event.

fields.name: version
fields.description: The version / revision of the rule being used for analysis.

fields.name: source
fields.title: Source
fields.description:
Source fields capture details about the sender of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Source fields are usually populated in conjunction with destination fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: IP address of the source (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: threat
fields.title: Threat
fields.description:
Fields to classify events and alerts according to a threat taxonomy such as the MITRE ATT&CK® framework.
These fields are for users to classify alerts from all of their sources (e.g. IDS, NGFW, etc.) within a common taxonomy. The threat.tactic.* fields are meant to capture the high level category of the threat (e.g. "impact"). The threat.technique.* fields are meant to capture which kind of approach is used by this detected threat, to accomplish the goal (e.g. "endpoint denial of service").

fields.name: enrichments
fields.description: A list of associated indicators objects enriching the event, and the context of that association/enrichment.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator
fields.description: Object containing associated indicators enriching the event.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.bus_type
fields.description: Bus type of the device, such as Nvme, Usb, FileBackedVirtual,... etc.

fields.description: DOS name of the device. DOS device name is in the format of driver letters such as C:, D:,...

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.file_system_type
fields.description:
Volume device file system type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device file system types: NTFS UDF

fields.description: NT name of the device. NT device name is in the format such as: \Device\HarddiskVolume2

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.product_id

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.serial_number

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.vendor_id
fields.description: VendorID of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.device.volume_device_type
fields.description:
Volume device type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device types: Disk File System CD-ROM File System

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.entry_modified

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.header_bytes
fields.description: First 16 bytes of file used to check file integrity.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.header_data
fields.description: First 16 bytes of file used to check file integrity.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.decompressed_size

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.encoding
