fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.identifier

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.score
fields.description: The score produced by the classification model.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.threshold

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.version

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.identifier
fields.description: Malware artifact identifier.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary
fields.description: Primary malware signature match.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.matches
fields.description: An array of bytes representing yara signature matches

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature
fields.description: Primary malware signature match.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash
fields.description: Primary malware signature hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash.sha256
fields.description: Primary malware signature sha256.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.id
fields.description: Primary malware signature id.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.name
fields.description: Primary malware signature name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.secondary
fields.description: An array of malware signature matches

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.version
fields.description: Primary malware signature version.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.monotonic_id
fields.description: File event monotonic ID.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original
fields.description: Original file information during a modification event.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.gid
fields.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.group
fields.description: Primary group name of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.mode
fields.description: Original file mode prior to a modification event

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.name
fields.description: Original file name prior to a modification event

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.owner

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.path
fields.description: Original file path prior to a modification event

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.Ext.original.uid
fields.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

fields.description: Path on endpoint where a copy of the file is being stored.  Used to make ephemeral files retrievable.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.accessed
fields.description:
Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.attributes
fields.description:
Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.created
fields.description:
File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.ctime
fields.description:
Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.device
fields.description: Device that is the source of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.directory
fields.description: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.drive_letter
fields.description:
Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.architecture
fields.description: Machine architecture of the ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.byte_order
fields.description: Byte sequence of ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.cpu_type
fields.description: CPU type of the ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.creation_date
fields.description: Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.exports
fields.description: List of exported element names and types.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.go_import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available [here](https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.go_imports
fields.description: List of imported Go language element names and types.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.go_imports_names_entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.go_imports_names_var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.go_stripped
fields.description: Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.abi_version
fields.description: Version of the ELF Application Binary Interface (ABI).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.class
fields.description: Header class of the ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.data
fields.description: Data table of the ELF header.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.entrypoint
fields.description: Header entrypoint of the ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.object_version
fields.description: "0x1" for original ELF files.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.os_abi
fields.description: Application Binary Interface (ABI) of the Linux OS.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.type
fields.description: Header type of the ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.header.version
fields.description: Version of the ELF header.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in an ELF file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is an ELF implementation of the Windows PE imphash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.imports
fields.description: List of imported element names and types.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.imports_names_entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.imports_names_var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections
fields.description:
An array containing an object for each section of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.sections.*`.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.chi2
fields.description: Chi-square probability distribution of the section.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.flags
fields.description: ELF Section List flags.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.name
fields.description: ELF Section List name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.physical_offset
fields.description: ELF Section List offset.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.physical_size
fields.description: ELF Section List physical size.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.type
fields.description: ELF Section List type.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.virtual_address
fields.description: ELF Section List virtual address.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.sections.virtual_size
fields.description: ELF Section List virtual size.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.segments
fields.description:
An array containing an object for each segment of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.segments.*`.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.segments.sections
fields.description: ELF object segment sections.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.segments.type
fields.description: ELF object segment type.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.shared_libraries
fields.description: List of shared libraries used by this ELF object.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.elf.telfhash
fields.description: telfhash symbol hash for ELF file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.extension
fields.description:
File extension, excluding the leading dot.
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.gid
fields.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.group
fields.description: Primary group name of the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.hash.ssdeep
fields.description: SSDEEP hash.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.inode
fields.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.mime_type
fields.description: MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml[IANA official types], where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.mode
fields.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.mtime
fields.description: Last time the file content was modified.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.name
fields.description: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.owner
fields.description: File owner's username.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.path
fields.description: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.architecture
fields.description: CPU architecture target for the file.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.company
fields.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.description
fields.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.file_version
fields.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.original_file_name
fields.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.pe.product
fields.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.size
fields.description:
File size in bytes.
Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.target_path
fields.description: Target path for symlinks.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.type
fields.description: File type (file, dir, or symlink).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.file.uid
fields.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.first_seen
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source first reported sighting this indicator.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.ip
fields.description: Identifies a threat indicator as an IP address (irrespective of direction).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.last_seen
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source last reported sighting this indicator.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.marking.tlp
fields.description: Traffic Light Protocol sharing markings.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.modified_at
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source last modified information for this indicator.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.port
fields.description: Identifies a threat indicator as a port number (irrespective of direction).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.provider
fields.description: The name of the indicator's provider.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.reference
fields.description: Reference URL linking to additional information about this indicator.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.data.bytes
fields.description:
Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.data.strings
fields.description:
Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.data.type
fields.description: Standard registry type for encoding contents

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.hive
fields.description: Abbreviated name for the hive.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.key
fields.description: Hive-relative path of keys.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.path
fields.description: Full path, including hive, key and value

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.registry.value
fields.description: Name of the value written.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.scanner_stats
fields.description: Count of AV/EDR vendors that successfully detected malicious file or URL.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.sightings
fields.description: Number of times this indicator was observed conducting threat activity.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.type
fields.description: Type of indicator as represented by Cyber Observable in STIX 2.0.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.domain
fields.description:
Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
If the URL contains a literal IPv6 address enclosed by `[` and `]` (IETF RFC 2732), the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the `domain` field.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.extension
fields.description:
The field contains the file extension from the original request url, excluding the leading dot.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.fragment
fields.description:
Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.full
fields.description: If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.original
fields.description:
Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.password
fields.description: Password of the request.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.path
fields.description: Path of the request, such as "/search".

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.port
fields.description: Port of the request, such as 443.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.query
fields.description:
The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.registered_domain
fields.description:
The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.scheme
fields.description:
Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.subdomain
fields.description:
The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.top_level_domain
fields.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.url.username
fields.description: Username of the request.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.alternative_names
fields.description: List of subject alternative names (SAN). Name types vary by certificate authority and certificate type but commonly contain IP addresses, DNS names (and wildcards), and email addresses.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.common_name
fields.description: List of common name (CN) of issuing certificate authority.
fields.example: Example SHA2 High Assurance Server CA

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.country
fields.description: List of country \(C) codes

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.distinguished_name
fields.description: Distinguished name (DN) of issuing certificate authority.
fields.example: C=US, O=Example Inc, OU=www.example.com, CN=Example SHA2 High Assurance Server CA

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.locality
fields.description: List of locality names (L)

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.organization
fields.description: List of organizations (O) of issuing certificate authority.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.organizational_unit
fields.description: List of organizational units (OU) of issuing certificate authority.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.issuer.state_or_province
fields.description: List of state or province names (ST, S, or P)

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.not_after
fields.description: Time at which the certificate is no longer considered valid.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.not_before
fields.description: Time at which the certificate is first considered valid.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.public_key_algorithm
fields.description: Algorithm used to generate the public key.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.public_key_curve
fields.description: The curve used by the elliptic curve public key algorithm. This is algorithm specific.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.public_key_exponent
fields.description: Exponent used to derive the public key. This is algorithm specific.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.public_key_size
fields.description: The size of the public key space in bits.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.serial_number
fields.description: Unique serial number issued by the certificate authority. For consistency, if this value is alphanumeric, it should be formatted without colons and uppercase characters.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.signature_algorithm
fields.description: Identifier for certificate signature algorithm. We recommend using names found in Go Lang Crypto library. See https://github.com/golang/go/blob/go1.14/src/crypto/x509/x509.go#L337-L353.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.common_name
fields.description: List of common names (CN) of subject.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.country
fields.description: List of country \(C) code

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.distinguished_name
fields.description: Distinguished name (DN) of the certificate subject entity.
fields.example: C=US, ST=California, L=San Francisco, O=Example, Inc., CN=shared.global.example.net

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.locality
fields.description: List of locality names (L)

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.organization
fields.description: List of organizations (O) of subject.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.organizational_unit
fields.description: List of organizational units (OU) of subject.

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.subject.state_or_province
fields.description: List of state or province names (ST, S, or P)

fields.name: enrichments.indicator.x509.version_number
fields.description: Version of x509 format.

fields.name: enrichments.matched.atomic
fields.description: Identifies the atomic indicator value that matched a local environment endpoint or network event.

fields.name: enrichments.matched.field
fields.description: Identifies the field of the atomic indicator that matched a local environment endpoint or network event.

fields.name: enrichments.matched.id
fields.description: Identifies the _id of the indicator document enriching the event.

fields.name: enrichments.matched.index
fields.description: Identifies the _index of the indicator document enriching the event.

fields.name: enrichments.matched.type
fields.description: Identifies the type of match that caused the event to be enriched with the given indicator

fields.name: framework
fields.description: Name of the threat framework used to further categorize and classify the tactic and technique of the reported threat. Framework classification can be provided by detecting systems, evaluated at ingest time, or retrospectively tagged to events.

fields.name: group.alias
fields.description:
The alias(es) of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group alias(es).

fields.name: group.id
fields.description:
The id of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group id.

fields.name: group.name
fields.description:
The name of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group name.

fields.name: group.reference
fields.description:
The reference URL of the group for a set of related intrusion activity that are tracked by a common name in the security community.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® group reference URL.

fields.name: indicator.as.number
fields.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

fields.name: indicator.as.organization.name
fields.description: Organization name.

fields.name: indicator.confidence
fields.description: Identifies the vendor-neutral confidence rating using the None/Low/Medium/High scale defined in Appendix A of the STIX 2.1 framework. Vendor-specific confidence scales may be added as custom fields.

fields.name: indicator.description
fields.description: Describes the type of action conducted by the threat.
fields.example: IP x.x.x.x was observed delivering the Angler EK.

fields.name: indicator.email.address
fields.description: Identifies a threat indicator as an email address (irrespective of direction).

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.bus_type
fields.description: Bus type of the device, such as Nvme, Usb, FileBackedVirtual,... etc.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.dos_name
fields.description: DOS name of the device. DOS device name is in the format of driver letters such as C:, D:,...

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.file_system_type
fields.description:
Volume device file system type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device file system types: NTFS UDF

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.nt_name
fields.description: NT name of the device. NT device name is in the format such as: \Device\HarddiskVolume2

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.product_id
fields.description: ProductID of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device if any.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.serial_number
fields.description: Serial Number of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device if any.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.vendor_id
fields.description: VendorID of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.device.volume_device_type
fields.description:
Volume device type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device types: Disk File System CD-ROM File System

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.entropy
fields.description: Entropy calculation of file's header and footer used to check file integrity.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.entry_modified
fields.description: Time of last status change.  See `st_ctim` member of `struct stat`.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.header_bytes
fields.description: First 16 bytes of file used to check file integrity.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.header_data
fields.description: First 16 bytes of file used to check file integrity.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.buffer
fields.description: The features extracted from this file and evaluated by the model.  Usually an array of floats.  Likely zlib-encoded.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.decompressed_size
fields.description: The decompressed size of buffer.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.features.data.encoding
fields.description: The encoding of buffer (e.g. zlib).

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.identifier
fields.description: The model's unique identifier.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.score
fields.description: The score produced by the classification model.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.threshold
fields.description: The score threshold for the model.  Files that score above this threshold are considered malicious.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.upx_packed
fields.description: Whether UPX packing was detected.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_classification.version
fields.description: The version of the model used.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature
fields.description: Nested version of malware_signature fieldset.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.all_names
fields.description: The concatenated names of all yara signatures

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.identifier
fields.description: Malware artifact identifier.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary
fields.description: Primary malware signature match.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.matches
fields.description: An array of bytes representing yara signature matches

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature
fields.description: Primary malware signature match.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash
fields.description: Primary malware signature hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash.sha256
fields.description: Primary malware signature sha256.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.id
fields.description: Primary malware signature id.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.primary.signature.name
fields.description: Primary malware signature name.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.secondary
fields.description: An array of malware signature matches

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.malware_signature.version
fields.description: Primary malware signature version.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.monotonic_id
fields.description: File event monotonic ID.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original
fields.description: Original file information during a modification event.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.gid
fields.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.group
fields.description: Primary group name of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.mode
fields.description: Original file mode prior to a modification event

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.name
fields.description: Original file name prior to a modification event

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.owner
fields.description: File owner's username.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.path
fields.description: Original file path prior to a modification event

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.original.uid
fields.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.quarantine_message
fields.description: Message describing quarantine results.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.quarantine_path
fields.description: Path on endpoint the quarantined file was originally.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.quarantine_result
fields.description: Boolean representing whether or not file quarantine succeeded.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.temp_file_path
fields.description: Path on endpoint where a copy of the file is being stored.  Used to make ephemeral files retrievable.

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.windows
fields.description: Platform-specific Windows fields

fields.name: indicator.file.Ext.windows.zone_identifier
fields.description: Windows zone identifier for a file

fields.name: indicator.file.accessed
fields.description:
Last time the file was accessed.
Note that not all filesystems keep track of access time.

fields.name: indicator.file.attributes
fields.description:
Array of file attributes.
Attributes names will vary by platform. Here's a non-exhaustive list of values that are expected in this field: archive, compressed, directory, encrypted, execute, hidden, read, readonly, system, write.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: indicator.file.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: indicator.file.created
fields.description:
File creation time.
Note that not all filesystems store the creation time.

fields.name: indicator.file.ctime
fields.description:
Last time the file attributes or metadata changed.
Note that changes to the file content will update `mtime`. This implies `ctime` will be adjusted at the same time, since `mtime` is an attribute of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.device
fields.description: Device that is the source of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.directory
fields.description: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: indicator.file.drive_letter
fields.description:
Drive letter where the file is located. This field is only relevant on Windows.
The value should be uppercase, and not include the colon.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.architecture
fields.description: Machine architecture of the ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.byte_order
fields.description: Byte sequence of ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.cpu_type
fields.description: CPU type of the ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.creation_date
fields.description: Extracted when possible from the file's metadata. Indicates when it was built or compiled. It can also be faked by malware creators.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.exports
fields.description: List of exported element names and types.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.go_import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the Go language imports in an ELF file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available [here](https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma).

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.go_imports
fields.description: List of imported Go language element names and types.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.go_imports_names_entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.go_imports_names_var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.go_stripped
fields.description: Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.abi_version
fields.description: Version of the ELF Application Binary Interface (ABI).

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.class
fields.description: Header class of the ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.data
fields.description: Data table of the ELF header.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.entrypoint
fields.description: Header entrypoint of the ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.object_version
fields.description: "0x1" for original ELF files.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.os_abi
fields.description: Application Binary Interface (ABI) of the Linux OS.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.type
fields.description: Header type of the ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.header.version
fields.description: Version of the ELF header.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in an ELF file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is an ELF implementation of the Windows PE imphash.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.imports
fields.description: List of imported element names and types.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.imports_names_entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.imports_names_var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of imported element names and types.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections
fields.description:
An array containing an object for each section of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.sections.*`.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.chi2
fields.description: Chi-square probability distribution of the section.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.entropy
fields.description: Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.flags
fields.description: ELF Section List flags.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.name
fields.description: ELF Section List name.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.physical_offset
fields.description: ELF Section List offset.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.physical_size
fields.description: ELF Section List physical size.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.type
fields.description: ELF Section List type.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the section.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.virtual_address
fields.description: ELF Section List virtual address.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.sections.virtual_size
fields.description: ELF Section List virtual size.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.segments
fields.description:
An array containing an object for each segment of the ELF file.
The keys that should be present in these objects are defined by sub-fields underneath `elf.segments.*`.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.segments.sections
fields.description: ELF object segment sections.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.segments.type
fields.description: ELF object segment type.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.shared_libraries
fields.description: List of shared libraries used by this ELF object.

fields.name: indicator.file.elf.telfhash
fields.description: telfhash symbol hash for ELF file.

fields.name: indicator.file.extension
fields.description:
File extension, excluding the leading dot.
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

fields.name: indicator.file.gid
fields.description: Primary group ID (GID) of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.group
fields.description: Primary group name of the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.hash.ssdeep
fields.description: SSDEEP hash.

fields.name: indicator.file.inode
fields.description: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

fields.name: indicator.file.mime_type
fields.description: MIME type should identify the format of the file or stream of bytes using https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml[IANA official types], where possible. When more than one type is applicable, the most specific type should be used.

fields.name: indicator.file.mode
fields.description: Mode of the file in octal representation.

fields.name: indicator.file.mtime
fields.description: Last time the file content was modified.

fields.name: indicator.file.name
fields.description: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

fields.name: indicator.file.owner
fields.description: File owner's username.

fields.name: indicator.file.path
fields.description: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.architecture
fields.description: CPU architecture target for the file.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.company
fields.description: Internal company name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.description
fields.description: Internal description of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.file_version
fields.description: Internal version of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.original_file_name
fields.description: Internal name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: indicator.file.pe.product
fields.description: Internal product name of the file, provided at compile-time.

fields.name: indicator.file.size
fields.description:
File size in bytes.
Only relevant when `file.type` is "file".

fields.name: indicator.file.target_path
fields.description: Target path for symlinks.

fields.name: indicator.file.type
fields.description: File type (file, dir, or symlink).

fields.name: indicator.file.uid
fields.description: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

fields.name: indicator.first_seen
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source first reported sighting this indicator.

fields.name: indicator.geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: indicator.geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: indicator.geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: indicator.geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: indicator.geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: indicator.geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: indicator.geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: indicator.geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: indicator.geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: indicator.geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: indicator.geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: indicator.ip
fields.description: Identifies a threat indicator as an IP address (irrespective of direction).

fields.name: indicator.last_seen
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source last reported sighting this indicator.

fields.name: indicator.marking.tlp
fields.description: Traffic Light Protocol sharing markings.

fields.name: indicator.modified_at
fields.description: The date and time when intelligence source last modified information for this indicator.

fields.name: indicator.port
fields.description: Identifies a threat indicator as a port number (irrespective of direction).

fields.name: indicator.provider
fields.description: The name of the indicator's provider.

fields.name: indicator.reference
fields.description: Reference URL linking to additional information about this indicator.

fields.name: indicator.registry.data.bytes
fields.description:
Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

fields.name: indicator.registry.data.strings
fields.description:
Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

fields.name: indicator.registry.data.type
fields.description: Standard registry type for encoding contents

fields.name: indicator.registry.hive
fields.description: Abbreviated name for the hive.

fields.name: indicator.registry.key
fields.description: Hive-relative path of keys.

fields.name: indicator.registry.path
fields.description: Full path, including hive, key and value

fields.name: indicator.registry.value
fields.description: Name of the value written.

fields.name: indicator.scanner_stats
fields.description: Count of AV/EDR vendors that successfully detected malicious file or URL.

fields.name: indicator.sightings
fields.description: Number of times this indicator was observed conducting threat activity.

fields.name: indicator.type
fields.description: Type of indicator as represented by Cyber Observable in STIX 2.0.

fields.name: indicator.url.domain
fields.description:
Domain of the url, such as "www.elastic.co".
In some cases a URL may refer to an IP and/or port directly, without a domain name. In this case, the IP address would go to the `domain` field.
If the URL contains a literal IPv6 address enclosed by `[` and `]` (IETF RFC 2732), the `[` and `]` characters should also be captured in the `domain` field.

fields.name: indicator.url.extension
fields.description:
The field contains the file extension from the original request url, excluding the leading dot.
The file extension is only set if it exists, as not every url has a file extension.
The leading period must not be included. For example, the value must be "png", not ".png".
Note that when the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

fields.name: indicator.url.fragment
fields.description:
Portion of the url after the `#`, such as "top".
The `#` is not part of the fragment.

fields.name: indicator.url.full
fields.description: If full URLs are important to your use case, they should be stored in `url.full`, whether this field is reconstructed or present in the event source.

fields.name: indicator.url.original
fields.description:
Unmodified original url as seen in the event source.
Note that in network monitoring, the observed URL may be a full URL, whereas in access logs, the URL is often just represented as a path.
This field is meant to represent the URL as it was observed, complete or not.

fields.name: indicator.url.password
fields.description: Password of the request.

fields.name: indicator.url.path
fields.description: Path of the request, such as "/search".

fields.name: indicator.url.port
fields.description: Port of the request, such as 443.

fields.name: indicator.url.query
fields.description:
The query field describes the query string of the request, such as "q=elasticsearch".
The `?` is excluded from the query string. If a URL contains no `?`, there is no query field. If there is a `?` but no query, the query field exists with an empty string. The `exists` query can be used to differentiate between the two cases.

fields.name: indicator.url.registered_domain
fields.description:
The highest registered url domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: indicator.url.scheme
fields.description:
Scheme of the request, such as "https".
Note: The `:` is not part of the scheme.

fields.name: indicator.url.subdomain
fields.description:
The subdomain portion of a fully qualified domain name includes all of the names except the host name under the registered_domain.  In a partially qualified domain, or if the the qualification level of the full name cannot be determined, subdomain contains all of the names below the registered domain.
For example the subdomain portion of "www.east.mydomain.co.uk" is "east". If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

fields.name: indicator.url.top_level_domain
fields.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: indicator.url.username
fields.description: Username of the request.

fields.name: indicator.x509.alternative_names
fields.description: List of subject alternative names (SAN). Name types vary by certificate authority and certificate type but commonly contain IP addresses, DNS names (and wildcards), and email addresses.

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.common_name
fields.description: List of common name (CN) of issuing certificate authority.
fields.example: Example SHA2 High Assurance Server CA

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.country
fields.description: List of country \(C) codes

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.distinguished_name
fields.description: Distinguished name (DN) of issuing certificate authority.
fields.example: C=US, O=Example Inc, OU=www.example.com, CN=Example SHA2 High Assurance Server CA

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.locality
fields.description: List of locality names (L)

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.organization
fields.description: List of organizations (O) of issuing certificate authority.

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.organizational_unit
fields.description: List of organizational units (OU) of issuing certificate authority.

fields.name: indicator.x509.issuer.state_or_province
fields.description: List of state or province names (ST, S, or P)

fields.name: indicator.x509.not_after
fields.description: Time at which the certificate is no longer considered valid.

fields.name: indicator.x509.not_before
fields.description: Time at which the certificate is first considered valid.

fields.name: indicator.x509.public_key_algorithm
fields.description: Algorithm used to generate the public key.

fields.name: indicator.x509.public_key_curve
fields.description: The curve used by the elliptic curve public key algorithm. This is algorithm specific.

fields.name: indicator.x509.public_key_exponent
fields.description: Exponent used to derive the public key. This is algorithm specific.

fields.name: indicator.x509.public_key_size
fields.description: The size of the public key space in bits.

fields.name: indicator.x509.serial_number
fields.description: Unique serial number issued by the certificate authority. For consistency, if this value is alphanumeric, it should be formatted without colons and uppercase characters.

fields.name: indicator.x509.signature_algorithm
fields.description: Identifier for certificate signature algorithm. We recommend using names found in Go Lang Crypto library. See https://github.com/golang/go/blob/go1.14/src/crypto/x509/x509.go#L337-L353.

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.common_name
fields.description: List of common names (CN) of subject.

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.country
fields.description: List of country \(C) code

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.distinguished_name
fields.description: Distinguished name (DN) of the certificate subject entity.
fields.example: C=US, ST=California, L=San Francisco, O=Example, Inc., CN=shared.global.example.net

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.locality
fields.description: List of locality names (L)

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.organization
fields.description: List of organizations (O) of subject.

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.organizational_unit
fields.description: List of organizational units (OU) of subject.

fields.name: indicator.x509.subject.state_or_province
fields.description: List of state or province names (ST, S, or P)

fields.name: indicator.x509.version_number
fields.description: Version of x509 format.

fields.name: software.id
fields.description:
The id of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software id.

fields.name: software.name
fields.description:
The name of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software name.

fields.name: software.platforms
fields.description:
The platforms of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®.
While not required, you can use MITRE ATT&CK® software platform values.

fields.name: software.reference
fields.description:
The reference URL of the software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software reference URL.

fields.name: software.type
fields.description:
The type of software used by this threat to conduct behavior commonly modeled using MITRE ATT&CK®.
While not required, you can use a MITRE ATT&CK® software type.

fields.name: tactic.id
fields.description: The id of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/ )

fields.name: tactic.name
fields.description: Name of the type of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/)

fields.name: tactic.reference
fields.description: The reference url of tactic used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® tactic, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002/ )

fields.name: technique.id
fields.description: The id of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

fields.name: technique.name
fields.description: The name of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

fields.name: technique.reference
fields.description: The reference url of technique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® technique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/)

fields.name: technique.subtechnique.id
fields.description: The full id of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)

fields.name: technique.subtechnique.name
fields.description: The name of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)

fields.name: technique.subtechnique.reference
fields.description: The reference url of subtechnique used by this threat. You can use a MITRE ATT&CK® subtechnique, for example. (ex. https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)

fields.name: user
fields.title: User
fields.description:
The user fields describe information about the user that is relevant to the event.
Fields can have one entry or multiple entries. If a user has more than one id, provide an array that includes all of them.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: User info prior to any setuid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: email
fields.description: User email address.

fields.name: full_name
fields.description: User's full name, if available.

fields.name: group.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: group.Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group.domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: hash
fields.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: Endpoint
fields.title: Endpoint
fields.description: Fields describing the state of the Elastic Endpoint when an event occurs.

fields.name: configuration
fields.description: Configuration fields represent the intended and applied setting for fields not part of a Policy setting This reflects what a given field is configured to do. The actual state of that same field is found in Endpoint.state

fields.name: configuration.isolation
fields.description: Configuration setting for Host Isolation from the network

fields.name: policy
fields.description: The policy fields are used to hold information about applied policy.

fields.name: policy.applied
fields.description: information about the policy that is applied

fields.name: policy.applied.actions
fields.description: actions applied during the application of the policy

fields.name: policy.applied.actions.message
fields.description: message about the application of the action to further qualify the status of the action

fields.name: policy.applied.actions.name
fields.description: name of the action that was applied

fields.name: policy.applied.actions.status
fields.description: the status of the action

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: build.original
fields.description:
Extended build information for the agent.
This field is intended to contain any build information that a data source may provide, no specific formatting is required.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.
