fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: Effective_process
fields.title: Effective_process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about an effective process.
The effective process is the process that requested the a specific action, without directly performing it.
Processes can have effective parents that differ from their regular parents. For example, on Windows, "wmic process call create notepad" will ask WmiPrvSE.exe to launch notepad.exe. WmiPrvSE will be notepad's parent, but the wmic will be the effective parent.
Events can have effective processes that differ from their regular processes. For example, on Windows, "reg add \\localhost\HKLM\Software\Foo /v Data /t REG_SZ /d 123"  will result in a registry event from the Remote Registry service (svchost.exe). In this case, the effective process will be reg.exe.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the effective process.

fields.name: executable
fields.description: Executable name for the effective process.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Process name for the effective process.

fields.name: pid
fields.description: Process ID.

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: destination
fields.title: Destination
fields.description:
Destination fields capture details about the receiver of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Destination fields are usually populated in conjunction with source fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: group
fields.title: Group
fields.description: The group fields are meant to represent groups that are relevant to the event.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.

fields.name: process
fields.title: Process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a process.
These fields can help you correlate metrics information with a process id/name from a log message.  The `process.pid` often stays in the metric itself and is copied to the global field for correlation.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.ancestry
fields.description: An array of entity_ids indicating the ancestors for this event

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: thread.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack
fields.description: Fields describing a stack frame.  call_stack is expected to be an array where each array element represents a stack frame.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.allocation_private_bytes
fields.description: The number of bytes in this memory allocation/image that are both +X and non-shareable. Non-zero values can indicate code hooking, patching, or hollowing.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.callsite_leading_bytes
fields.description: Hex opcode bytes preceding the callsite

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.callsite_trailing_bytes
fields.description: Hex opcode bytes after the callsite (where control will return to)

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.protection
fields.description: Protection of the page containing this instruction.  This is `R-X' by default if omitted.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.symbol_info
fields.description: The nearest symbol for `instruction_pointer`.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_summary
fields.description: Concatentation of the non-repeated modules in the call stack.

fields.name: thread.Ext.hardware_breakpoint_set
fields.description: Whether a hardware breakpoint was set for the thread. This field is omitted if false.

fields.name: thread.id
fields.description: Thread ID.

fields.name: registry
fields.title: Registry
fields.description: Fields related to Windows Registry operations.

fields.name: data.bytes
fields.description:
Original bytes written with base64 encoding.
For Windows registry operations, such as SetValueEx and RegQueryValueEx, this corresponds to the data pointed by `lp_data`. This is optional but provides better recoverability and should be populated for REG_BINARY encoded values.

fields.name: data.strings
fields.description:
Content when writing string types.
Populated as an array when writing string data to the registry. For single string registry types (REG_SZ, REG_EXPAND_SZ), this should be an array with one string. For sequences of string with REG_MULTI_SZ, this array will be variable length. For numeric data, such as REG_DWORD and REG_QWORD, this should be populated with the decimal representation (e.g `"1"`).

fields.name: data.type
fields.description: Standard registry type for encoding contents

fields.name: hive
fields.description: Abbreviated name for the hive.

fields.name: key
fields.description: Hive-relative path of keys.

fields.name: path
fields.description: Full path, including hive, key and value

fields.name: value
fields.description: Name of the value written.

fields.name: source
fields.title: Source
fields.description:
Source fields capture details about the sender of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Source fields are usually populated in conjunction with destination fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: user
fields.title: User
fields.description:
The user fields describe information about the user that is relevant to the event.
Fields can have one entry or multiple entries. If a user has more than one id, provide an array that includes all of them.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: User info prior to any setuid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: email
fields.description: User email address.

fields.name: full_name
fields.description: User's full name, if available.

fields.name: group.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: group.Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group.domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: hash
fields.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: ephemeral_id
fields.description:
Ephemeral identifier of this agent (if one exists).
This id normally changes across restarts, but `agent.id` does not.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Custom name of the agent.
This is a name that can be given to an agent. This can be helpful if for example two Filebeat instances are running on the same host but a human readable separation is needed on which Filebeat instance data is coming from.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: cloud
fields.title: Cloud
fields.description: Fields related to the cloud or infrastructure the events are coming from.

fields.name: account.id
fields.description:
The cloud account or organization id used to identify different entities in a multi-tenant environment.
Examples: AWS account id, Google Cloud ORG Id, or other unique identifier.

fields.name: instance.name
fields.description: Instance name of the host machine.

fields.name: project.id
fields.description:
The cloud project identifier.
Examples: Google Cloud Project id, Azure Project id.

fields.name: provider
fields.description: Name of the cloud provider. Example values are aws, azure, gcp, or digitalocean.

fields.name: region
fields.description: Region in which this host, resource, or service is located.

fields.footnote:
Examples: If Metricbeat is running on an EC2 host and fetches data from its host, the cloud info contains the data about this machine. If Metricbeat runs on a remote machine outside the cloud and fetches data from a service running in the cloud, the field contains cloud data from the machine the service is running on.
The cloud fields may be self-nested under cloud.origin.* and cloud.target.* to describe origin or target service's cloud information in the context of incoming or outgoing requests, respectively. However, the fieldsets cloud.origin.* and cloud.target.* must not be confused with the root cloud fieldset that is used to describe the cloud context of the actual service under observation. The fieldset cloud.origin.* may only be used in the context of incoming requests or events to provide the originating service's cloud information. The fieldset cloud.target.* may only be used in the context of outgoing requests or events to describe the target service's cloud information.

fields.name: container
fields.title: Container
fields.description:
Container fields are used for meta information about the specific container that is the source of information.
These fields help correlate data based containers from any runtime.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique container id.

fields.name: image.hash.all
fields.description: An array of digests of the image the container was built on. Each digest consists of the hash algorithm and value in this format: `algorithm:value`. Algorithm names should align with the field names in the ECS hash field set.

fields.name: image.name
fields.description: Name of the image the container was built on.

fields.name: image.tag
fields.description: Container image tags.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Container name.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: destination
fields.title: Destination
fields.description:
Destination fields capture details about the receiver of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Destination fields are usually populated in conjunction with source fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: group
fields.title: Group
fields.description: The group fields are meant to represent groups that are relevant to the event.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: boot.id
fields.description: Linux boot uuid taken from /proc/sys/kernel/random/boot_id. Note the boot_id value from /proc may or may not be the same in containers as on the host. Some container runtimes will bind mount a new boot_id value onto the proc file in each container.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: pid_ns_ino
fields.description: This is the inode number of the namespace in the namespace file system (nsfs). Unsigned int inum in include/linux/ns_common.h.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.

fields.name: orchestrator
fields.title: Orchestrator
fields.description: Fields that describe the resources which container orchestrators manage or act upon.

fields.name: cluster.id
fields.description: Unique ID of the cluster.

fields.name: cluster.name
fields.description: Name of the cluster.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Namespace in which the action is taking place.

fields.name: resource.ip
fields.description: IP address assigned to the resource associated with the event being observed. In the case of a Kubernetes Pod, this array would contain only one element: the IP of the Pod (as opposed to the Node on which the Pod is running).

fields.name: resource.name
fields.description: Name of the resource being acted upon.

fields.name: resource.parent.type
fields.description: Type or kind of the parent resource associated with the event being observed. In Kubernetes, this will be the name of a built-in workload resource (e.g., Deployment, StatefulSet, DaemonSet).

fields.name: resource.type
fields.description: Type of resource being acted upon.

fields.name: package
fields.title: Package
fields.description: These fields contain information about an installed software package. It contains general information about a package, such as name, version or size. It also contains installation details, such as time or location.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Package name

fields.name: process
fields.title: Process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a process.
These fields can help you correlate metrics information with a process id/name from a log message.  The `process.pid` often stays in the metric itself and is copied to the global field for correlation.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.ancestry
fields.description: An array of entity_ids indicating the ancestors for this event

fields.name: Ext.architecture
fields.description: Process architecture.  It can differ from host architecture.

fields.name: Ext.authentication_id
fields.description: Process authentication ID

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.created_suspended
fields.description: A heuristic indicating if the CREATE_SUSPENDED flag was passed to the Win32 CreateProcess API. Not valid for direct syscalls.

fields.name: Ext.defense_evasions
fields.description: List of defense evasions found in this process. These defense evasions can make it harder to inspect a process and/or cause abnormal OS behavior. Examples tools that can cause defense evasions include Process Doppelganging and Process Herpaderping.

fields.name: Ext.device.bus_type
fields.description: Bus type of the device, such as Nvme, Usb, FileBackedVirtual,... etc.

fields.name: Ext.device.dos_name
fields.description: DOS name of the device. DOS device name is in the format of driver letters such as C:, D:,...

fields.name: Ext.device.file_system_type
fields.description:
Volume device file system type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device file system types: NTFS UDF

fields.name: Ext.device.nt_name
fields.description: NT name of the device. NT device name is in the format such as: \Device\HarddiskVolume2

fields.name: Ext.device.product_id
fields.description: ProductID of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device if any.

fields.name: Ext.device.serial_number
fields.description: Serial Number of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device if any.

fields.name: Ext.device.vendor_id
fields.description: VendorID of the device. It is provided by the vendor of the device.

fields.name: Ext.device.volume_device_type
fields.description:
Volume device type.
Following are examples of the most frequently seen volume device types: Disk File System CD-ROM File System

fields.name: Ext.dll.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.dll.Ext.mapped_address
fields.description: The base address where this module is loaded.

fields.name: Ext.dll.Ext.mapped_size
fields.description: The size of this module's memory mapping, in bytes.

fields.name: Ext.dll.name
fields.description:
Name of the library.
This generally maps to the name of the file on disk.

fields.name: Ext.dll.path
fields.description: Full file path of the library.

fields.name: Ext.effective_parent.entity_id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the effective process.

fields.name: Ext.effective_parent.executable
fields.description: Executable name for the effective process.

fields.name: Ext.effective_parent.name
fields.description: Process name for the effective process.

fields.name: Ext.effective_parent.pid
fields.description: Process ID.

fields.name: Ext.memfd
fields.description: Object for memfd events.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flag_allow_seal
fields.description: Allow sealing operations on this file.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flag_cloexec
fields.description: Sets the the close-on-exec flag on the new file descriptor.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flag_exec
fields.description: Exec flag is set for file.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flag_hugetlb
fields.description: The anonymous file will be created in the hugetlbfs filesystem using huge pages.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flag_noexec_seal
fields.description: Sets both NOEXEC and MFD_ALLOW_SEALING.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.flags
fields.description: Flags passed to the memfd operation.

fields.name: Ext.memfd.name
fields.description: Filename for the created file. Appears in /proc/self/fd.

fields.name: Ext.mitigation_policies
fields.description: Process mitigation policies include SignaturePolicy, DynamicCodePolicy, UserShadowStackPolicy, ControlFlowGuardPolicy, etc. Examples include Microsoft only, CF Guard, User Shadow Stack enabled

fields.name: Ext.protection
fields.description: Indicates the protection level of this process.  Uses the same syntax as Process Explorer. Examples include PsProtectedSignerWinTcb, PsProtectedSignerWinTcb-Light, and PsProtectedSignerWindows-Light.

fields.name: Ext.ptrace
fields.description: Object for ptrace events.

fields.name: Ext.ptrace.child_pid
fields.description: PID of the ptrace target.

fields.name: Ext.ptrace.request
fields.description: ptrace request.

fields.name: Ext.relative_file_creation_time
fields.description: Number of seconds since the process's file was created. This number may be negative if the file's timestamp is in the future.

fields.name: Ext.relative_file_name_modify_time
fields.description: Number of seconds since the process's name was modified. This information can come from the NTFS MFT. This number may be negative if the file's timestamp is in the future.

fields.name: Ext.session
fields.description: Session information for the current process

fields.name: Ext.session_info.authentication_package
fields.description: Name of authentication package used to log on, such as NTLM, Kerberos, or CloudAP

fields.name: Ext.session_info.client_address
fields.description: Client's IPv4 or IPv6 address as a string, if available.

fields.name: Ext.session_info.id
fields.description: Session ID

fields.name: Ext.session_info.logon_type
fields.description: Session logon type.  Examples include Interactive, Network, and Service.

fields.name: Ext.session_info.relative_logon_time
fields.description: Process creation time, relative to logon time, in seconds.

fields.name: Ext.session_info.relative_password_age
fields.description: Process creation time, relative to the last time the password was changed, in seconds.

fields.name: Ext.session_info.user_flags
fields.description: List of user flags associated with this logon session. Examples include LOGON_NTLMV2_ENABLED and LOGON_WINLOGON.

fields.name: Ext.shmget
fields.description: Object for shmget events.

fields.name: Ext.shmget.flags
fields.description: flags passed to shmget.

fields.name: Ext.shmget.key
fields.description: Key passed to the shmget request.

fields.name: Ext.shmget.size
fields.description: Requested size.

fields.name: Ext.token.elevation
fields.description: Whether the token is elevated or not

fields.name: Ext.token.elevation_level
fields.description: What level of elevation the token has

fields.name: Ext.token.elevation_type
fields.description: What level of elevation the token has

fields.name: Ext.token.integrity_level_name
fields.description: Human readable integrity level.

fields.name: Ext.token.security_attributes
fields.description: Array of security attributes of the token, retrieved via the  TokenSecurityAttributes class.

fields.name: Ext.trusted
fields.description: Whether or not the process is a trusted application

fields.name: Ext.trusted_descendant
fields.description: Whether or not the process is a descendent of a trusted application

fields.name: args
fields.description:
Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: args_count
fields.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: end
fields.description: The time the process ended.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.args
fields.description:
Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entry_leader.args_count
fields.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

fields.name: entry_leader.attested_groups.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.attested_user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.attested_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entry_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.entry_meta.source.ip
fields.description: IP address of the source (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: entry_leader.entry_meta.type
fields.description:
The entry type for the entry session leader. Values include: init(e.g systemd), sshd, ssm, kubelet, teleport, terminal, console
Note: This field is only set on process.session_leader.

fields.name: entry_leader.executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: entry_leader.group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.interactive
fields.description:
Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

fields.name: entry_leader.name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.session_leader.start
fields.description: The time the process started.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.start
fields.description: The time the process started.

fields.name: entry_leader.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.real_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.same_as_process
fields.description:
This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.saved_user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.start
fields.description: The time the process started.

fields.name: entry_leader.supplemental_groups.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: entry_leader.supplemental_groups.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: entry_leader.tty
fields.description: Information about the controlling TTY device. If set, the process belongs to an interactive session.

fields.name: entry_leader.tty.char_device.major
fields.description: The major number identifies the driver associated with the device. The character device's major and minor numbers can be algorithmically combined to produce the more familiar terminal identifiers such as "ttyS0" and "pts/0". For more details, please refer to the Linux kernel documentation.

fields.name: entry_leader.tty.char_device.minor
fields.description: The minor number is used only by the driver specified by the major number; other parts of the kernel don’t use it, and merely pass it along to the driver. It is common for a driver to control several devices; the minor number provides a way for the driver to differentiate among them.

fields.name: entry_leader.user.id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.user.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: entry_leader.working_directory
fields.description: The working directory of the process.

fields.name: env_vars
fields.description:
Array of environment variable bindings. Captured from a snapshot of the environment at the time of execution.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: exit_code
fields.description:
The exit code of the process, if this is a termination event.
The field should be absent if there is no exit code for the event (e.g. process start).

fields.name: group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group_leader.args
fields.description:
Array of process arguments, starting with the absolute path to the executable.
May be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: group_leader.args_count
fields.description:
Length of the process.args array.
This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

fields.name: group_leader.command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: group_leader.group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group_leader.group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group_leader.pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: group_leader.real_group.id

fields.name: group_leader.real_group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group_leader.real_user.id

fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: group_leader.working_directory

fields.name: hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: hash.sha512

fields.name: io
fields.description:
A chunk of input or output (IO) from a single process.
This field only appears on the top level process object, which is the process that wrote the output or read the input.

fields.name: io.max_bytes_per_process_exceeded
fields.description: If true, the process producing the output has exceeded the max_kilobytes_per_process configuration setting.

fields.name: io.text
fields.description:
A chunk of output or input sanitized to UTF-8.
Best efforts are made to ensure complete lines are captured in these events. Assumptions should NOT be made that multiple lines will appear in the same event. TTY output may contain terminal control codes such as for cursor movement, so some string queries may not match due to terminal codes inserted between characters of a word.

fields.name: io.total_bytes_captured
fields.description: The total number of bytes captured in this event.

fields.name: io.total_bytes_skipped
fields.description: The total number of bytes that were not captured due to implementation restrictions such as buffer size limits. Implementors should strive to ensure this value is always zero

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: parent.Ext.architecture

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: parent.Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: parent.Ext.protection
fields.description: Indicates the protection level of this process.  Uses the same syntax as Process Explorer. Examples include PsProtectedSignerWinTcb, PsProtectedSignerWinTcb-Light, and PsProtectedSignerWindows-Light.

fields.name: parent.Ext.real
fields.description: The field set containing process info in case of any pid spoofing. This is mainly useful for process.parent.

fields.name: parent.Ext.real.pid
fields.description: For process.parent this will be the ppid of the process that actually spawned the current process.

fields.name: parent.Ext.user
fields.description: User associated with the running process.

fields.name: parent.args_count

fields.name: parent.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: parent.code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.

fields.name: parent.code_signature.subject_name

The team identifier used to sign the process.

fields.name: parent.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.

fields.name: parent.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.

The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: parent.interactive
fields.description:
Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.
Process interactivity is inferred from the processes file descriptors. If the character device for the controlling tty is the same as stdin and stderr for the process, the process is considered interactive.
Note: A non-interactive process can belong to an interactive session and is simply one that does not have open file descriptors reading the controlling TTY on FD 0 (stdin) or writing to the controlling TTY on FD 2 (stderr). A backgrounded process is still considered interactive if stdin and stderr are connected to the controlling TTY.

fields.name: session_leader.same_as_process
fields.description:
This boolean is used to identify if a leader process is the same as the top level process.
For example, if `process.group_leader.same_as_process = true`, it means the process event in question is the leader of its process group. Details under `process.*` like `pid` would be the same under `process.group_leader.*` The same applies for both `process.session_leader` and `process.entry_leader`.
This field exists to the benefit of EQL and other rule engines since it's not possible to compare equality between two fields in a single document. e.g `process.entity_id` = `process.group_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the process group leader) OR `process.entity_id` = `process.entry_leader.entity_id` (top level process is the entry session leader)
Instead these rules could be written like: `process.group_leader.same_as_process: true` OR `process.entry_leader.same_as_process: true`
Note: This field is only set on `process.entry_leader`, `process.session_leader` and `process.group_leader`.

fields.name: source
fields.title: Source
fields.description:
Source fields capture details about the sender of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Source fields are usually populated in conjunction with destination fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code

fields.name: geo.timezone

Fields can have one entry or multiple entries. If a user has more than one id, provide an array that includes all of them.
