fields.name: destination
fields.title: Destination
fields.description:
Destination fields capture details about the receiver of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Destination fields are usually populated in conjunction with source fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: IP address of the destination (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: port
fields.description: Port of the destination.

fields.name: dll
fields.title: DLL
fields.description:
These fields contain information about code libraries dynamically loaded into processes.

Many operating systems refer to "shared code libraries" with different names, but this field set refers to all of the following:
* Dynamic-link library (`.dll`) commonly used on Windows
* Shared Object (`.so`) commonly used on Unix-like operating systems
* Dynamic library (`.dylib`) commonly used on macOS

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: hash.sha256
fields.description: SHA256 hash.

fields.name: path
fields.description: Full file path of the library.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: end
fields.description: `event.end` contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: start
fields.description: `event.start` contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.

fields.name: network
fields.title: Network
fields.description:
The network is defined as the communication path over which a host or network event happens.
The network.* fields should be populated with details about the network activity associated with an event.

fields.name: transport
fields.description:
Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

fields.name: process
fields.title: Process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a process.
These fields can help you correlate metrics information with a process id/name from a log message.  The `process.pid` often stays in the metric itself and is copied to the global field for correlation.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.ancestry
fields.description: An array of entity_ids indicating the ancestors for this event

fields.name: Ext.api.behaviors
fields.description:
A list of observed behaviors.
  "cross-process" - the observed activity was between two processes
  "parent-child" - the observed activity was between a parent process and its child
  "native_api" - a call was made directly to the Native API rather than the Win32 API
  "direct_syscall" - a syscall instruction originated outside of the Native API layer
  "proxy_call" - the call stack may indicate of a proxied API call to mask the true source
  "sensitive_api" - executable non-image memory is unexpectedly calling a sensitive API
  "shellcode" - suspicious executable non-image memory is calling a sensitive API
  "image_hooked" - an entry in the callstack appears to have been hooked
  "image_indirect_call" - an entry in the callstack was preceded by a call to a dynamically resolved function
  "image_rop" - no call instruction preceded an entry in the call stack
  "image_rwx" - an entry in the callstack is writable
  "unbacked_rwx" - an entry in the callstack is non-image and writable
  "truncated_stack" - call stack is unexpected truncated due to malicious tampering or system load
  "allocate_shellcode" - a region of non-image executable memory allocated more executable memory
  "execute_fluctuation" - the PAGE_EXECUTE protection is unexpectedly fluctuating
  "write_fluctuation" - the PAGE_WRITE protection of executable memory is unexpectedly fluctuating
  "hook_api" - a change to the memory protection of a small executable image memory region was made
  "hollow_image" - a change to the memory protection of a large executable image memory region was made
  "hook_unbacked" - a change to the memory protection of a small executable non-image memory was made
  "hollow_unbacked" - a change to the memory protection of a large executable non-image memory was made
  "guarded_code" - executable memory was unexpectedly marked as PAGE_GUARD
  "hidden_code" - executable memory was unexpectedly marked as PAGE_NOACCESS
  "execute_shellcode" - a region of non-image executable memory was unexpectedly transferred control
  "hardware_breakpoint_set" - a hardware breakpoint was set
  "rapid_background_polling" - a suspicious process which does rapid input polling via GetAsyncKeyState API was observed
  "multiple_polling_processes" - multiple suspicious processes which do rapid input polling via the GetAsyncKeyState API were observed
  "pid_spoofing" - The acting process details may have been spoofed to hide the true origin
  "legacy_api" - a deprecated or superseded API was called

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata
fields.description: Information related to the API call.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.amsi_filenames
fields.description: A list of filenames previously scanned by AMSI.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.amsi_logs
fields.description: Information related to previous AMSI scans.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.amsi_logs.entries
fields.description: A subset of the AMSI content buffers scanned prior to this event.
fields.example: [ "[Ref].Assembly.GetType('System.Management.Automation.AmsiUtils').GetField('amsiInitFailed', 'NonPublic,Static').SetValue($null, $true);Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class Kernel32 {   [DllImport("kernel32.dll")]   public static extern IntPtr VirtualAlloc(IntPtr lpAddress, uint dwSize, uint flAllocationType, uint flProtect);}" ]

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.amsi_logs.type
fields.description: The AMSI content type scanned prior to this event.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.background_callcount
fields.description: This field indicates a number of all GetAsyncKeyState api calls, including unsuccessful calls, between the last successful GetAsyncKeyState call.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.client_is_local
fields.description: Indicates whether a method was called locally or remotely. It will be true if called locally, and false if called remotely.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.client_machine
fields.description: Client process's machine name (provided by the client and potentially untrustworthy).

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.client_machine_fqdn
fields.description: Client process's machine name FQDN (provided by the client and potentially untrustworthy).

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.client_process_id
fields.description: Client process id

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.ms_since_last_keyevent
fields.description: This field indicates the elapsed time in milliseconds since the last GetAsyncKeyState event.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.procedure_symbol
fields.description: Summary of the hook procedure.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.return_value
fields.description: Return value of RegisterRawInputDevices API call.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.security_descriptor
fields.description: The security descriptor of the device.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.start_address_allocation_protection
fields.description: Memory protection attributes associated with the starting address of a thread.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.start_address_module
fields.description: Name of the module associated with the starting address of a thread.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.target_address_name
fields.description: The name of the memory region targeted by the API call.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.target_address_path
fields.description: The path of the memory region targeted by the API call.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.thread_info_flags
fields.description: Thread info flags.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.visible_windows_count
fields.description: Number of visible windows owned by the caller thread.

fields.name: Ext.api.metadata.windows_count
fields.description: Number of windows owned by the caller thread.

fields.name: Ext.api.name
fields.description: The name of the API, usually the name of the function or system call.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters
fields.description: Parameter values passed to the API call.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.address
fields.description: The target memory address.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.allocation_type
fields.description: The type of memory allocation. Corresponds to `MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION.State`

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.app_name
fields.description: The application name requesting the AMSI scan.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.argument1
fields.description: The first argument to the procedure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.argument2
fields.description: The second argument to the procedure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.argument3
fields.description: The third argument to the procedure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.buffer
fields.description: The content associated with an AMSI scan.
fields.example: [Ref].Assembly.GetType('System.Management.Automation.AmsiUtils').GetField('amsiInitFailed', 'NonPublic,Static').SetValue($null, $true);Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class Kernel32 {   [DllImport("kernel32.dll")]   public static extern IntPtr VirtualAlloc(IntPtr lpAddress, uint dwSize, uint flAllocationType, uint flProtect);}'; [Kernel32]::VirtualAlloc([IntPtr]::Zero, 0x1234, 0x1000, 0x20);

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.consumer_details
fields.description: Provides specific information about an event consumer, including its configuration, such as the command it executes, associated SID, and the consumer's name.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.consumer_name
fields.description: Consumer Name. Consumers specify what should happen when the conditions in the Event Filter are triggered.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.consumer_type
fields.description:
An example list of consumer type.
  "ActiveScriptEventConsumer" - Executes a predefined script in an arbitrary scripting language when an event is delivered to it.
  "CommandLineEventConsumer" - Launches an arbitrary process in the local system context when an event is delivered to it.
  "LogFileEventConsumer" - Writes customized strings to a text log file when events are delivered to it.
  "NTEventLogEventConsumer" - Logs a specific message to the Windows event log when an event is delivered to it.
  "SMTPEventConsumer" - Sends an email message using SMTP each time an event is delivered to it.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.content_name
fields.description: The content name, typically a filename, associated with an AMSI scan.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.context_flags
fields.description: The bitmask of CPU registers operated on by this call. Corresponds to `CONTEXT.ContextFlags`

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.desired_access
fields.description: This parameter indicates the string value of the `DesiredAccess` field  to `OpenProcess` or `OpenThread`.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.desired_access_numeric
fields.description: This parameter indicates the numeric value of the `DesiredAccess` field passed to `OpenProcess` or `OpenThread`.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.device
fields.description: The name of the device object.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.driver
fields.description: The name of the driver object.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.eax
fields.description: The x86 EAX general purpose register. Return value in __cdecl, __stdcall, __thiscall and __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.ebp
fields.description: The x86 EBP frame pointer register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.ebx
fields.description: The x86 EBX general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.ecx
fields.description: The x86 ECX general purpose register. First argument in __fastcall and __thiscall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.edi
fields.description: The x86 EDI general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.edx
fields.description: The x86 EDX general purpose register. Second argument in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.eip
fields.description: The x86 EIP instruction pointer register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.esi
fields.description: The x86 ESI general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.esp
fields.description: The x86 ESP stack pointer register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.event_filter_details
fields.description: Provide an overview of the query that define when an event should be triggered.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.event_filter_name
fields.description: Event filter name. An event filter is a WMI class that defines which events WMI delivers to a consumer.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.flags
fields.description: Mode flag that specifies how to interpret the information provided by UsagePage and Usage. Third member RAWINPUTDEVICE structure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.handle_type
fields.description: This parameter indicates whether the detected access was attempt against a process or a thread.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.hook_module
fields.description: DLL containing the hook procedure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.hook_type
fields.description: Type of hook procedure to be installed.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.io_control_code
fields.description: The I/O control code for the requested device operation.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.namespace
fields.description: WMI namespace to which the connection is made.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.operation
fields.description: Specifies the connection or request to WMI

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.procedure
fields.description: The memory address of the procedure or function.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.protection
fields.description: The memory protection for the region of pages. Corresponds to `MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION.Protect`

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.protection_old
fields.description: The previous memory protection returned by the API call. Corresponds to `MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION.Protect`

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.r8
fields.description: The x64 R8 general purpose register. Third argument in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.r9
fields.description: The x64 R9 general purpose register. Fourth argument in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rax
fields.description: The x64 RAX general purpose register. Return value in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rbp
fields.description: The x64 RBP general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rbx
fields.description: The x64 RBX general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rcx
fields.description: The x64 RCX general purpose register. First argument in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rdi
fields.description: The x64 RDI general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rdx
fields.description: The x64 RDX general purpose register. Second argument in a __fastcall.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rip
fields.description: The x64 RIP instruction pointer register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rsi
fields.description: The x64 RSI general purpose register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.rsp
fields.description: The x64 RSP stack pointer register.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.size
fields.description: The size.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.usage
fields.description: This parameter indicates the specific device (Usage) within the Usage Page. Second member RAWINPUTDEVICE structure.

fields.name: Ext.api.parameters.usage_page
fields.description: This parameter indicates the top-level collection (Usage Page) of the device. First member RAWINPUTDEVICE structure.

fields.name: Ext.api.summary
fields.description: The summary of the API call and its parameters.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.created_suspended
fields.description: A heuristic indicating if the CREATE_SUSPENDED flag was passed to the Win32 CreateProcess API. Not valid for direct syscalls.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.allocation_base
fields.description: Base address of the memory allocation containing the memory region.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.allocation_protection
fields.description: Original memory protection requested when the memory was allocated. Example values include "RWX" and "R-X".

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.allocation_size
fields.description: Original memory size requested when the memory was allocated.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.allocation_type
fields.description: The memory allocation type. Example values include "IMAGE", "MAPPED", and "PRIVATE".

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.bytes_address
fields.description: The address where bytes_compressed begins.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.bytes_allocation_offset
fields.description: Offset of bytes_address the memory allocation. Equal to bytes_address - allocation_base.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.bytes_compressed
fields.description: Up to 4MB of raw data from the memory allocation. This is compressed with zlib.To reduce data volume, this is de-duplicated on the endpoint, and may be missing from many alerts if the same data would be sent multiple times.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.bytes_compressed_present
fields.description: Whether bytes_compressed is present in this event.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.hash.sha256
fields.description: The sha256 of the memory region.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.all_names

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.identifier

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.primary

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.primary.matches
fields.description: The first matching details.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.primary.signature.hash.sha256

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.primary.signature.name

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary.matches

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary.signature.hash
fields.description: hash of second file matching signature.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary.signature.hash.sha256
fields.description: sha256 hash of second file matching signature.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary.signature.id
fields.description: The id of the second yara rule matched.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.secondary.signature.name
fields.description: The name of the second yara rule matched.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.malware_signature.version
fields.description: malware signature version

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_path
fields.description: If the memory corresponds to a file mapping, this is the file's path.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.dotnet
fields.description: Whether this file is a .NET PE

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections
fields.description: The file's relevant sections, if it is a PE

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.description: SHA384 hash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections.hash.sha512
fields.description: SHA512 hash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections.hash.ssdeep
fields.description: SSDEEP hash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections.hash.tlsh

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.sections.name

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.streams
fields.description: The file's streams, if it is a PE

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.streams.hash.md5
fields.description: MD5 hash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.Ext.streams.hash.sha1
fields.description: SHA1 hash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.go_import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the Go language imports in a PE file excluding standard library imports. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
The algorithm used to calculate the Go symbol hash and a reference implementation are available [here](https://github.com/elastic/toutoumomoma).

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.go_imports
fields.description: List of imported Go language element names and types.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.go_imports_names_entropy

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.go_imports_names_var_entropy
fields.description: Variance for Shannon entropy calculation from the list of Go imports.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.go_stripped
fields.description: Set to true if the file is a Go executable that has had its symbols stripped or obfuscated and false if an unobfuscated Go executable.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.imphash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An imphash -- or import hash -- can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
Learn more at https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2014/01/tracking-malware-import-hashing.html.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.import_hash
fields.description:
A hash of the imports in a PE file. An import hash can be used to fingerprint binaries even after recompilation or other code-level transformations have occurred, which would change more traditional hash values.
This is a synonym for imphash.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.mapped_pe.pehash
fields.description:
A hash of the PE header and data from one or more PE sections. An pehash can be used to cluster files by transforming structural information about a file into a hash value.
Learn more at https://www.usenix.org/legacy/events/leet09/tech/full_papers/wicherski/wicherski_html/index.html.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.region_protection
fields.description: Memory protection of the memory region. Example values include "RWX" and "R-X".
