fields.description: First 64 bytes at the region base address.

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.region_state
fields.description: State of the memory region. Example values include "RESERVE", "COMMIT", and "FREE".

fields.name: Ext.memory_region.strings
fields.description: Array of strings found within the memory region.

fields.name: Ext.protection
fields.description: Indicates the protection level of this process.  Uses the same syntax as Process Explorer. Examples include PsProtectedSignerWinTcb, PsProtectedSignerWinTcb-Light, and PsProtectedSignerWindows-Light.

fields.name: Ext.token.integrity_level_name
fields.description: Human readable integrity level.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: command_line
fields.description:
Full command line that started the process, including the absolute path to the executable, and all arguments.
Some arguments may be filtered to protect sensitive information.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: thread.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack
fields.description: Fields describing a stack frame.  call_stack is expected to be an array where each array element represents a stack frame.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.allocation_private_bytes
fields.description: The number of bytes in this memory allocation/image that are both +X and non-shareable. Non-zero values can indicate code hooking, patching, or hollowing.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.callsite_leading_bytes
fields.description: Hex opcode bytes preceding the callsite

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.callsite_trailing_bytes
fields.description: Hex opcode bytes after the callsite (where control will return to)

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.instruction_pointer
fields.description: The return address of this stack frame.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.module_path
fields.description: The path to the DLL/module containing `instruction_pointer`.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.protection
fields.description: Protection of the page containing this instruction.  This is `R-X' by default if omitted.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.protection_provenance
fields.description: The name of the memory region that last modified the protection of this page.  "Unbacked" can indicate shellcode.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack.symbol_info
fields.description: The nearest symbol for `instruction_pointer`.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_contains_unbacked
fields.description: Indicates whether the creating thread's stack contains frames pointing outside any known executable image.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module
fields.description: The module that installed the final API hook in the call stack.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature
fields.description: Code signature of the call_stack_final_hook_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.hash
fields.description: Hashes of the call_stack_final_hook_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.hash.sha256
fields.description: The sha256 of the call_stack_final_hook_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_hook_module.path
fields.description: The file path of the call_stack_final_hook_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module
fields.description: The final non-win32 module in the call stack.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.allocation_private_bytes
fields.description: The number of bytes in this memory region that are both +X and non-shareable. Non-zero values can indicate code hooking, patching, or hollowing.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature
fields.description: Code signature of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.hash
fields.description: Hashes of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.hash.sha256
fields.description: The sha256 of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.name
fields.description: The file name of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.path
fields.description: The file path of the call_stack_final_user_module.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.protection
fields.description: The memory protection for the acting region of pages. Corresponds to `MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION.Protect`

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.protection_provenance
fields.description: The name of the memory region that caused the last modification of the protection of this page. "Unbacked" may indicate shellcode.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.protection_provenance_path
fields.description: The path of the module that caused the last modification the protection of this page.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_final_user_module.reason
fields.description: The unexpected call_stack_summary that led to an "Undetermined" protection_provenance.

fields.name: thread.Ext.call_stack_summary
fields.description: Concatentation of the non-repeated modules in the call stack.

fields.name: thread.id
fields.description: Thread ID.

fields.name: user
fields.title: User
fields.description:
The user fields describe information about the user that is relevant to the event.
Fields can have one entry or multiple entries. If a user has more than one id, provide an array that includes all of them.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

sample_event.message: Endpoint API event - hand-crafted with a superset of fields

fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: destination
fields.title: Destination
fields.description:
Destination fields capture details about the receiver of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Destination fields are usually populated in conjunction with source fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: address
fields.description:
Some event destination addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.

fields.name: as.number
fields.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

fields.name: as.organization.name
fields.description: Organization name.

fields.name: bytes
fields.description: Bytes sent from the destination to the source.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
The domain name of the destination system.
This value may be a host name, a fully qualified domain name, or another host naming format. The value may derive from the original event or be added from enrichment.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: IP address of the destination (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: packets
fields.description: Packets sent from the destination to the source.

fields.name: port
fields.description: Port of the destination.

fields.name: registered_domain
fields.description:
The highest registered destination domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: top_level_domain
fields.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: dns
fields.title: DNS
fields.description:
Fields describing DNS queries and answers.
DNS events should either represent a single DNS query prior to getting answers (`dns.type:query`) or they should represent a full exchange and contain the query details as well as all of the answers that were provided for this query (`dns.type:answer`).

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.options
fields.description: DNS options field, uint64, representing as a keyword to avoid overflows in ES

fields.name: Ext.status
fields.description: DNS status field, uint32

fields.name: question.name
fields.description:
The name being queried.
If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.

fields.name: question.registered_domain
fields.description:
The highest registered domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: question.subdomain
fields.description:
The subdomain is all of the labels under the registered_domain.
If the domain has multiple levels of subdomain, such as "sub2.sub1.example.com", the subdomain field should contain "sub2.sub1", with no trailing period.

fields.name: question.top_level_domain
fields.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: question.type
fields.description: The type of record being queried.

fields.name: resolved_ip
fields.description:
Array containing all IPs seen in `answers.data`.
The `answers` array can be difficult to use, because of the variety of data formats it can contain. Extracting all IP addresses seen in there to `dns.resolved_ip` makes it possible to index them as IP addresses, and makes them easier to visualize and query for.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: group
fields.title: Group
fields.description: The group fields are meant to represent groups that are relevant to the event.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.

fields.name: http
fields.title: HTTP
fields.description: Fields related to HTTP activity. Use the `url` field set to store the url of the request.

fields.name: request.body.bytes
fields.description: Size in bytes of the request body.

fields.name: request.body.content
fields.description: The full HTTP request body.

fields.name: request.bytes
fields.description: Total size in bytes of the request (body and headers).

fields.name: response.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: response.Ext.version
fields.description: HTTP version

fields.name: response.body.bytes
fields.description: Size in bytes of the response body.

fields.name: response.body.content
fields.description: The full HTTP response body.

fields.name: response.bytes
fields.description: Total size in bytes of the response (body and headers).

fields.name: response.status_code
fields.description: HTTP response status code.

fields.name: network
fields.title: Network
fields.description:
The network is defined as the communication path over which a host or network event happens.
The network.* fields should be populated with details about the network activity associated with an event.

fields.name: bytes
fields.description:
Total bytes transferred in both directions.
If `source.bytes` and `destination.bytes` are known, `network.bytes` is their sum.

fields.name: community_id
fields.description:
A hash of source and destination IPs and ports, as well as the protocol used in a communication. This is a tool-agnostic standard to identify flows.
Learn more at https://github.com/corelight/community-id-spec.

fields.name: direction
fields.description:
Direction of the network traffic.
When mapping events from a host-based monitoring context, populate this field from the host's point of view, using the values "ingress" or "egress".
When mapping events from a network or perimeter-based monitoring context, populate this field from the point of view of the network perimeter, using the values "inbound", "outbound", "internal" or "external".
Note that "internal" is not crossing perimeter boundaries, and is meant to describe communication between two hosts within the perimeter. Note also that "external" is meant to describe traffic between two hosts that are external to the perimeter. This could for example be useful for ISPs or VPN service providers.

fields.name: iana_number
fields.description: IANA Protocol Number (https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml). Standardized list of protocols. This aligns well with NetFlow and sFlow related logs which use the IANA Protocol Number.

fields.name: packets
fields.description:
Total packets transferred in both directions.
If `source.packets` and `destination.packets` are known, `network.packets` is their sum.

fields.name: protocol
fields.description:
In the OSI Model this would be the Application Layer protocol. For example, `http`, `dns`, or `ssh`.
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

fields.name: transport
fields.description:
Same as network.iana_number, but instead using the Keyword name of the transport layer (udp, tcp, ipv6-icmp, etc.)
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
In the OSI Model this would be the Network Layer. ipv4, ipv6, ipsec, pim, etc
The field value must be normalized to lowercase for querying.

fields.name: process
fields.title: Process
fields.description:
These fields contain information about a process.
These fields can help you correlate metrics information with a process id/name from a log message.  The `process.pid` often stays in the metric itself and is copied to the global field for correlation.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.ancestry
fields.description: An array of entity_ids indicating the ancestors for this event

fields.name: Ext.code_signature
fields.description: Nested version of ECS code_signature fieldset.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: Ext.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.exists
fields.description: Boolean to capture if a signature is present.

fields.name: code_signature.signing_id
fields.description:
The identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the application manufactured by a software vendor. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.status
fields.description:
Additional information about the certificate status.
This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: code_signature.subject_name
fields.description: Subject name of the code signer

fields.name: code_signature.team_id
fields.description:
The team identifier used to sign the process.
This is used to identify the team or vendor of a software product. The field is relevant to Apple *OS only.

fields.name: code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: entry_leader.parent.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: executable
fields.description: Absolute path to the process executable.

fields.name: group_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Process name.
Sometimes called program name or similar.

fields.name: parent.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: parent.group_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: pid
fields.description: Process id.

fields.name: session_leader.entity_id
fields.description:
Unique identifier for the process.
The implementation of this is specified by the data source, but some examples of what could be used here are a process-generated UUID, Sysmon Process GUIDs, or a hash of some uniquely identifying components of a process.
Constructing a globally unique identifier is a common practice to mitigate PID reuse as well as to identify a specific process over time, across multiple monitored hosts.

fields.name: thread.id
fields.description: Thread ID.

fields.name: source
fields.title: Source
fields.description:
Source fields capture details about the sender of a network exchange/packet. These fields are populated from a network event, packet, or other event containing details of a network transaction.
Source fields are usually populated in conjunction with destination fields. The source and destination fields are considered the baseline and should always be filled if an event contains source and destination details from a network transaction. If the event also contains identification of the client and server roles, then the client and server fields should also be populated.

fields.name: address
fields.description:
Some event source addresses are defined ambiguously. The event will sometimes list an IP, a domain or a unix socket.  You should always store the raw address in the `.address` field.
Then it should be duplicated to `.ip` or `.domain`, depending on which one it is.

fields.name: as.number
fields.description: Unique number allocated to the autonomous system. The autonomous system number (ASN) uniquely identifies each network on the Internet.

fields.name: as.organization.name
fields.description: Organization name.

fields.name: bytes
fields.description: Bytes sent from the source to the destination.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
The domain name of the source system.
This value may be a host name, a fully qualified domain name, or another host naming format. The value may derive from the original event or be added from enrichment.

fields.name: geo.city_name
fields.description: City name.

fields.name: geo.continent_code
fields.description: Two-letter code representing continent's name.

fields.name: geo.continent_name
fields.description: Name of the continent.

fields.name: geo.country_iso_code
fields.description: Country ISO code.

fields.name: geo.country_name
fields.description: Country name.

fields.name: geo.location
fields.description: Longitude and latitude.

fields.name: geo.name
fields.description:
User-defined description of a location, at the level of granularity they care about.
Could be the name of their data centers, the floor number, if this describes a local physical entity, city names.
Not typically used in automated geolocation.

fields.name: geo.postal_code
fields.description:
Postal code associated with the location.
Values appropriate for this field may also be known as a postcode or ZIP code and will vary widely from country to country.

fields.name: geo.region_iso_code
fields.description: Region ISO code.

fields.name: geo.region_name
fields.description: Region name.

fields.name: geo.timezone
fields.description: The time zone of the location, such as IANA time zone name.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: IP address of the source (IPv4 or IPv6).

fields.name: packets
fields.description: Packets sent from the source to the destination.

fields.name: port
fields.description: Port of the source.

fields.name: registered_domain
fields.description:
The highest registered source domain, stripped of the subdomain.
For example, the registered domain for "foo.example.com" is "example.com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last two labels will not work well for TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: top_level_domain
fields.description:
The effective top level domain (eTLD), also known as the domain suffix, is the last part of the domain name. For example, the top level domain for example.com is "com".
This value can be determined precisely with a list like the public suffix list (http://publicsuffix.org). Trying to approximate this by simply taking the last label will not work well for effective TLDs such as "co.uk".

fields.name: user
fields.title: User
fields.description:
The user fields describe information about the user that is relevant to the event.
Fields can have one entry or multiple entries. If a user has more than one id, provide an array that includes all of them.

fields.name: Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: Ext.real
fields.description: User info prior to any setuid operations.

fields.name: Ext.real.id
fields.description: One or multiple unique identifiers of the user.

fields.name: Ext.real.name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the directory the user is a member of.
For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: email
fields.description: User email address.

fields.name: full_name
fields.description: User's full name, if available.

fields.name: group.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: group.Ext.real
fields.description: Group info prior to any setgid operations.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.Ext.real.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: group.domain
fields.description: Name of the directory the group is a member of. For example, an LDAP or Active Directory domain name.

fields.name: group.id
fields.description: Unique identifier for the group on the system/platform.

fields.name: group.name
fields.description: Name of the group.

fields.name: hash
fields.description:
Unique user hash to correlate information for a user in anonymized form.
Useful if `user.id` or `user.name` contain confidential information and cannot be used.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique identifier of the user.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Short name or login of the user.

fields.name: @timestamp
fields.description:
Date/time when the event originated.
This is the date/time extracted from the event, typically representing when the event was generated by the source.
If the event source has no original timestamp, this value is typically populated by the first time the event was received by the pipeline.
Required field for all events.

fields.name: message
fields.description:
For log events the message field contains the log message, optimized for viewing in a log viewer.
For structured logs without an original message field, other fields can be concatenated to form a human-readable summary of the event.
If multiple messages exist, they can be combined into one message.

fields.name: Endpoint
fields.title: Endpoint
fields.description: Fields describing the state of the Elastic Endpoint when an event occurs.

fields.name: metrics
fields.description: Metrics fields hold the endpoint and system's performance metrics

fields.name: metrics.cpu
fields.description: CPU statistics

fields.name: metrics.cpu.endpoint
fields.description: CPU metrics for the endpoint

fields.name: metrics.cpu.endpoint.histogram
fields.description: This field defines an elasticsearch histogram field (https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/histogram.html#histogram) The values field includes 20 buckets (each bucket is 5%) representing the cpu usage The counts field includes 20 buckets of how many times the endpoint's cpu usage fell into each bucket

fields.name: metrics.cpu.endpoint.latest
fields.description: Average CPU over the last sample interval

fields.name: metrics.cpu.endpoint.mean
fields.description: Average CPU load used by the endpoint

fields.name: metrics.disks
fields.description: An array of disk information for the host

fields.name: metrics.disks.device
fields.description: Device name

fields.name: metrics.disks.endpoint_drive
fields.description: This field will be present and set to true only for the drive that holds the installed endpoint

fields.name: metrics.disks.free
fields.description: The number of bytes marked as free on the disk

fields.name: metrics.disks.fstype
fields.description: The file system type for the drive

fields.name: metrics.disks.mount
fields.description: The disks mount location

fields.name: metrics.disks.total
fields.description: The size of the disk in bytes

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume
fields.description: Statistics about sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.alerts.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.alerts.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.alerts.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.alerts.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of API Event sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent API Event documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources
fields.description: An array of API Event document statistics per source

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of API Event sent documents from source

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent API Event documents from source

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources.source
fields.description: API Event document source name

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed API Event documents from source

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.sources.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed API Event documents from source

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed API Event documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.api_events.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed API Event documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.diagnostic_alerts.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.diagnostic_alerts.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.diagnostic_alerts.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.diagnostic_alerts.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.dns_events.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.dns_events.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.dns_events.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.dns_events.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.file_events.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.file_events.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.file_events.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.file_events.suppressed_count
fields.description: Number of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.library_events.sent_bytes
fields.description: Total size of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.library_events.sent_count
fields.description: Number of sent documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.library_events.suppressed_bytes
fields.description: Total size of suppressed documents

fields.name: metrics.documents_volume.library_events.suppressed_count

This is useful for logging cryptographic errors with the certificate validity or trust status. Leave unpopulated if the validity or trust of the certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: metrics.system_impact.process.code_signature.trusted
fields.description:
Stores the trust status of the certificate chain.
Validating the trust of the certificate chain may be complicated, and this field should only be populated by tools that actively check the status.

fields.name: metrics.system_impact.process.code_signature.valid
fields.description:
Boolean to capture if the digital signature is verified against the binary content.
Leave unpopulated if a certificate was unchecked.

fields.name: agent
fields.title: Agent
fields.description:
The agent fields contain the data about the software entity, if any, that collects, detects, or observes events on a host, or takes measurements on a host.
Examples include Beats. Agents may also run on observers. ECS agent.* fields shall be populated with details of the agent running on the host or observer where the event happened or the measurement was taken.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique identifier of this agent (if one exists).
Example: For Beats this would be beat.id.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of the agent.
The agent type always stays the same and should be given by the agent used. In case of Filebeat the agent would always be Filebeat also if two Filebeat instances are run on the same machine.

fields.name: version
fields.description: Version of the agent.

fields.footnote: Examples: In the case of Beats for logs, the agent.name is filebeat. For APM, it is the agent running in the app/service. The agent information does not change if data is sent through queuing systems like Kafka, Redis, or processing systems such as Logstash or APM Server.

fields.name: data_stream
fields.title: data_stream
fields.description: Fields describing the new indexing strategy <type>-<dataset>-<namespace>

fields.name: dataset
fields.description: Data stream dataset name.

fields.name: namespace
fields.description: Data stream namespace.

fields.name: type
fields.description: Data stream type.

fields.name: ecs
fields.title: ECS
fields.description: Meta-information specific to ECS.

fields.name: version
fields.description:
ECS version this event conforms to. `ecs.version` is a required field and must exist in all events.
When querying across multiple indices -- which may conform to slightly different ECS versions -- this field lets integrations adjust to the schema version of the events.

fields.name: event
fields.title: Event
fields.description:
The event fields are used for context information about the log or metric event itself.
A log is defined as an event containing details of something that happened. Log events must include the time at which the thing happened. Examples of log events include a process starting on a host, a network packet being sent from a source to a destination, or a network connection between a client and a server being initiated or closed. A metric is defined as an event containing one or more numerical measurements and the time at which the measurement was taken. Examples of metric events include memory pressure measured on a host and device temperature. See the `event.kind` definition in this section for additional details about metric and state events.

fields.name: action
fields.description:
The action captured by the event.
This describes the information in the event. It is more specific than `event.category`. Examples are `group-add`, `process-started`, `file-created`. The value is normally defined by the implementer.

fields.name: category
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the second level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.category` represents the "big buckets" of ECS categories. For example, filtering on `event.category:process` yields all events relating to process activity. This field is closely related to `event.type`, which is used as a subcategory.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple categories.

fields.name: code
fields.description:
Identification code for this event, if one exists.
Some event sources use event codes to identify messages unambiguously, regardless of message language or wording adjustments over time. An example of this is the Windows Event ID.

fields.name: created
fields.description:
`event.created` contains the date/time when the event was first read by an agent, or by your pipeline.
This field is distinct from `@timestamp` in that `@timestamp` typically contain the time extracted from the original event.
In most situations, these two timestamps will be slightly different. The difference can be used to calculate the delay between your source generating an event, and the time when your agent first processed it. This can be used to monitor your agent's or pipeline's ability to keep up with your event source.
In case the two timestamps are identical, `@timestamp` should be used.

fields.name: dataset
fields.description:
Name of the dataset.
If an event source publishes more than one type of log or events (e.g. access log, error log), the dataset is used to specify which one the event comes from.
It's recommended but not required to start the dataset name with the module name, followed by a dot, then the dataset name.

fields.name: end
fields.description: `event.end` contains the date when the event ended or when the activity was last observed.

fields.name: hash
fields.description: Hash (perhaps logstash fingerprint) of raw field to be able to demonstrate log integrity.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Unique ID to describe the event.

fields.name: ingested
fields.description:
Timestamp when an event arrived in the central data store.
This is different from `@timestamp`, which is when the event originally occurred.  It's also different from `event.created`, which is meant to capture the first time an agent saw the event.
In normal conditions, assuming no tampering, the timestamps should chronologically look like this: `@timestamp` < `event.created` < `event.ingested`.

fields.name: kind
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the highest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.kind` gives high-level information about what type of information the event contains, without being specific to the contents of the event. For example, values of this field distinguish alert events from metric events.
The value of this field can be used to inform how these kinds of events should be handled. They may warrant different retention, different access control, it may also help understand whether the data is coming in at a regular interval or not.

fields.name: module
fields.description:
Name of the module this data is coming from.
If your monitoring agent supports the concept of modules or plugins to process events of a given source (e.g. Apache logs), `event.module` should contain the name of this module.

fields.name: outcome
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the lowest level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.outcome` simply denotes whether the event represents a success or a failure from the perspective of the entity that produced the event.
Note that when a single transaction is described in multiple events, each event may populate different values of `event.outcome`, according to their perspective.
Also note that in the case of a compound event (a single event that contains multiple logical events), this field should be populated with the value that best captures the overall success or failure from the perspective of the event producer.
Further note that not all events will have an associated outcome. For example, this field is generally not populated for metric events, events with `event.type:info`, or any events for which an outcome does not make logical sense.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
Source of the event.
Event transports such as Syslog or the Windows Event Log typically mention the source of an event. It can be the name of the software that generated the event (e.g. Sysmon, httpd), or of a subsystem of the operating system (kernel, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing).

fields.name: sequence
fields.description:
Sequence number of the event.
The sequence number is a value published by some event sources, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the timestamp precision.

fields.name: severity
fields.description:
The numeric severity of the event according to your event source.
What the different severity values mean can be different between sources and use cases. It's up to the implementer to make sure severities are consistent across events from the same source.
The Syslog severity belongs in `log.syslog.severity.code`. `event.severity` is meant to represent the severity according to the event source (e.g. firewall, IDS). If the event source does not publish its own severity, you may optionally copy the `log.syslog.severity.code` to `event.severity`.

fields.name: start
fields.description: `event.start` contains the date when the event started or when the activity was first observed.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
This is one of four ECS Categorization Fields, and indicates the third level in the ECS category hierarchy.
`event.type` represents a categorization "sub-bucket" that, when used along with the `event.category` field values, enables filtering events down to a level appropriate for single visualization.
This field is an array. This will allow proper categorization of some events that fall in multiple event types.

fields.name: host
fields.title: Host
fields.description:
A host is defined as a general computing instance.
ECS host.* fields should be populated with details about the host on which the event happened, or from which the measurement was taken. Host types include hardware, virtual machines, Docker containers, and Kubernetes nodes.

fields.name: architecture
fields.description: Operating system architecture.

fields.name: domain
fields.description:
Name of the domain of which the host is a member.
For example, on Windows this could be the host's Active Directory domain or NetBIOS domain name. For Linux this could be the domain of the host's LDAP provider.

fields.name: hostname
fields.description:
Hostname of the host.
It normally contains what the `hostname` command returns on the host machine.

fields.name: id
fields.description:
Unique host id.
As hostname is not always unique, use values that are meaningful in your environment.
Example: The current usage of `beat.name`.

fields.name: ip
fields.description: Host ip addresses.

fields.name: mac
fields.description:
Host MAC addresses.
The notation format from RFC 7042 is suggested: Each octet (that is, 8-bit byte) is represented by two [uppercase] hexadecimal digits giving the value of the octet as an unsigned integer. Successive octets are separated by a hyphen.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
Name of the host.
It can contain what hostname returns on Unix systems, the fully qualified domain name (FQDN), or a name specified by the user. The recommended value is the lowercase FQDN of the host.

fields.name: os.Ext
fields.description: Object for all custom defined fields to live in.

fields.name: os.Ext.variant
fields.description: A string value or phrase that further aid to classify or qualify the operating system (OS).  For example the distribution for a Linux OS will be entered in this field.

fields.name: os.family
fields.description: OS family (such as redhat, debian, freebsd, windows).

fields.name: os.full
fields.description: Operating system name, including the version or code name.

fields.name: os.kernel
fields.description: Operating system kernel version as a raw string.

fields.name: os.name
fields.description: Operating system name, without the version.

fields.name: os.platform
fields.description: Operating system platform (such centos, ubuntu, windows).

fields.name: os.type
fields.description:
Use the `os.type` field to categorize the operating system into one of the broad commercial families.
If the OS you're dealing with is not listed as an expected value, the field should not be populated. Please let us know by opening an issue with ECS, to propose its addition.

fields.name: os.version
fields.description: Operating system version as a raw string.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Type of host.
For Cloud providers this can be the machine type like `t2.medium`. If vm, this could be the container, for example, or other information meaningful in your environment.

fields.name: uptime
fields.description: Seconds the host has been up.
